Headline: : Winter Weather Continues to Affect Flights in the Northeast Through Saturday
Story: continental.com provides latest flight information and operations summary       HOUSTON, March 17 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Continental Airlines (NYSE: CAL) today announced that due to the impact of Friday's winter storm, there will be further delays and cancellations to flights in the Northeast through Saturday.  All flights to and from Newark Liberty International Airport have been cancelled through noon eastern time, with the exception of CO 9 from Newark to Narita departing at 11:10 a.m.     Customers scheduled to travel on Saturday are encouraged to check on the status of their flight prior to heading to the airport.     Continental has extended travel options for customers whose flight plans may be affected by the weather.  Travelers scheduled on flights on Saturday or Sunday may wish to delay commencement of their trip. Customers ticketed for travel through March 18, to or from the affected areas in the Northeast, are permitted a one-time date or time change to their flights without penalty for rescheduled travel originating by March 25.  Customers wishing to reschedule their trips should contact Continental reservations at 800-525-0280.     For up-to-date information regarding the status of a specific flight, the fastest and easiest source is http://www.continental.com - Travel re-accommodations.  An overview of Continental operations is available at http://www.continental.com - Flight Status - Today's Operations.  Automated flight status information is also available at 800-784-4444.    SOURCE  Continental Airlines       /CONTACT: Houston Corporate Communications: +1-713-324-5080, corpcomm@coair.com      /Web site: http://www.continental.com      /Web site: http://www.continental.com/company/news     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 05:00 ET (09:00 GMT)

Headline: Japan Hankyu, Hanshin Dept Stores To Merge Ops In Oct-Kyodo
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Japan's Hankyu Department Stores Inc. (8242.TO) and Hanshin Department Stores Ltd. plan to integrate their operations under a holding company in October, Kyodo news agency reported Saturday, citing sources familiar with the matter.   The two Osaka-based department store operators will serve as business companies under the envisaged holding firm, retaining their respective names, the sources said, according to Kyodo.   They will aim to increase management efficiency and survive intensifying competition through the merger, they said, according to Kyodo.   The two are now working out details of the merger, including the name of the holding company, the sources said, according to Kyodo.   The department industry has been experiencing realignment. Osaka-based Daimaru Inc. and Nagoya-based Matsuzakaya Holdings Co. (3051.TO) announced earlier this month that they will integrate under a holding company in September to become Japan's biggest department group, Kyodo reported.   Hankyu and Hanshin railway operators already completed their management integration last year. Hankyu Hanshin Holdings Inc. (9042.TO) was created through the merger of Hankyu Holdings Inc. and Hanshin Electric Railway Co., the report said.   The integration of Hankyu and Hanshin department store operators will be included in a medium-term business plan to be announced by Hankyu Hanshin Holdings, probably on March 26, the sources said, according to Kyodo.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 01:43 ET (05:43 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(3/19) One Way To Play It
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Cadbury shares may not get any sweeter soon. That's the view of Credit Suisse's quantitative trading and derivatives strategy desk following last week's big gain. So, it's advising clients to consider "strangling" them.   This strategy is often used by investors when they think a stock will stay in a trading range, and that the volatility of its options will thus decrease. Credit Suisse recommends selling June 560-pence puts, and selling June 650-pence calls. (The stock closed Friday at 610.50 pence. There are 100 pence in a British pound, each worth about 1.93 U.S. cents.) The firm says the trade will be profitable if the shares remain between 536 and 674 pence. These options give the stock room to fall 14.1% or rise 8%. The maximum profit: 24 pence.   The firm's sum-of-the-parts valuation puts a price of 580 to 590 pence on the shares.   The danger here is that, if the stock were to trade above 650 pence, investors who sold the "strangle" would be short the shares and might have to cover. Conversely, if the stock slid 560 pence, they'd effectively be long the stock. So anything that boosts volatility a lot wouldn't be sweet for users of this strategy.   (See related article: "A Sweetener for Cadbury Schweppes" -- Barron's March 19, 2007)   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Minnesota Target Shifts Muslims Who Refuse To Ring Up Pork
Story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)--Muslim cashiers at some local Target stores who object to ringing up products that contain pork are being shifted to other positions, the national retailer said Saturday.   Some Muslim cashiers had declined to scan products such as bacon because doing so would conflict with their religious beliefs. They would ask other cashiers to ring up such purchases, or some customers scanned the items themselves.   Minneapolis-based Target Corp. (TGT) has offered the cashiers the option of wearing gloves, shifting to other positions or transferring to other stores.   "We are confident that this is a reasonable solution for our guests and team members," Target spokeswoman Paula Thornton-Greear said in a statement e-mailed to The Associated Press on Saturday.   Islam teaches that eating pork is forbidden, and some Muslims feel selling or handling pork is also forbidden because it would make them complicit in the sins of others.   Greear said the situation was a local problem only.   "It is not an issue in most of our stores in the Twin Cities," she said in separate comments via e-mail. "There is also no indication that this is an issue in the Minnesota market overall or nationwide."   As the local Muslim population grows, fueled by immigration from East African countries such as Somalia, efforts by Muslims to live by the rules of their faith often conflict with American realities.   In one dispute, some Muslim cab drivers who serve Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport refuse to take passengers who are carrying alcohol. The Metropolitan Airports Commission is expected to vote in April on a proposal that would hand out 30-day license suspensions to cabbies who refuse service for any reason.   Suhara Robla, who works at a SuperTarget, told the Star Tribune newspaper that more than a dozen Muslim cashiers were asked Thursday to do other jobs.   "They told all of us who don't touch pork to go to the sales floor," she told the newspaper. "They really didn't say why. They just said it was a new policy."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 16:34 ET (20:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from March 8 through March 14.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Metro One Telecommunications (INFO)   A group including Strategic Turnaround Equity Partners asked for a board seat and changes at Metro One "to maximize shareholder value." Shareholder Everest Special Situations Fund wrote to Metro One calling for Chairman William Rutherford to resign. The Strategic group agreed with much of what Everest expressed; it holds 720,028 shares (11.55% of total outstanding).     Topps (TOPP)   An investor group including Topps' director Arnaud Ajdler and Crescendo Investments II wrote to Topps' board, criticizing it for actions taken at a March 13 meeting. As reported, the board blocked two directors from officially monitoring acquisition offers that might compete with a recently announced -- and controversial -- bid to buy the trading-card company for about $385 million. Topps expressed concern over whether Ajdler and investor Timothy Brog could "adequately represent the best interests of the company's stockholders" given their "publicly stated opposition" to Topps' proposed merger with Tornante Co. and Madison Dearborn Partners. The Crescendo group holds 2,547,700 shares (6.6%).     Advocat (AVCA)   Bristol Investment Fund has urged Advocat to retain a financial adviser to begin an auction process, solicit offers and engage in discussions with potential strategic buyers. It wants Advocat to form a committee of outside directors to evaluate offers and other alternatives. Bristol recommends that AVCA focus on a stock-buyback plan. Bristol holds 256,861 shares (4.4%).     InfoSpace (INSP)   A shareholder group including Castlerigg Master Investments and Sandell Asset Management recommends that InfoSpace commit to $15 million in cost-cutting and return at least $300 million of its cash balance to shareholders through a share buyback and a dividend. The group also suggested that, if management doesn't close the value gap, the board should engage a financial adviser to sell INSP in whole or part. The shareholder group owns about 2.77 million shares (8.8%).     Diversa (DVSA)   T. Rowe Price (TROW) opposes Diversa's proposed merger with Celunol. The investor expressed "dissatisfaction" with the proposed transaction and intends to determine what alternative courses of action may better serve its interests. T. Rowe holds about 3.43 million shares (7.7%).     Original Filings     Educational Development (EDUC)     Investor Richard Scott reported ownership of 313,138 shares (9.01%), after buying them at $7 each in a private placement March 6 -- making Scott the second-largest shareholder of the company.     Increases in Holdings     Ultratech (UTEK)   Thales Fund Management boosted its stake to about 3.37 million shares (14.5%), from 2.8 million shares (12.1%) reported on Feb. 22. Thales Fund expects to acquire additional shares. In January, the fund disclosed it had sent a letter to UTEK asking it to consider a sale of the company as a way to maximize shareholder value.     Lesco (LSCO)   A group of funds managed by Mario Gabelli's Gamco Investors (GBL) reported ownership of 644,311 shares (7.04%), after buying them from Feb. 20 to March 9 at $14.25 to $27.39 each.     Openwave Systems (OPWV)   A group including Harbinger Capital Partners Master Fund I and Harbert Management raised its stake to 10.61 million shares (11.2%), after buying 610,000 on March 6-7 at $8.20 to $8.30 each.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) The Trader: Best Subprime Analogy: -2-
Story: For one thing, tightening credit will hit the lower end of the housing spectrum harder, and KB Homes serves a wider swath of first-time home owners. The average price of homes sold by KB is $277,000, compared with $690,000 for Toll, a luxury homebuilder. Headline: Menu Foods Recalling 46 Dog Food, 37 Cat Food Brands
Story: UNION, N.J. (AP)--Menu Foods, the Ontario-based company that produces recently recalled pet food, said Saturday it was recalling dog food sold under 46 brands and cat food sold under 37 brands including Iams, Nutro and Eukanuba. The food was distributed throughout the U.S., Canada and Mexico by major retailers such as Wal-Mart (WMT), Kroger (KR)  and Safeway (SWY).   An unknown number of cats and dogs had suffered kidney failure and about 10 died after eating the affected pet food, the company said.   Many stores that sold the affected brands frantically pulled packages off shelves.   At a Petsmart (PETM) store in Union, Silviene Grzybowski became worried when the four types of Iams products she buys for her cat, Smokey, had vanished from shelves. The cat was very sick and had not been eating for days, she said.   "The vet told us to buy her her favorite food, but I'm going to call the vet right now," Grzybowski said, looking at an announcement Petsmart had taped to shelves announcing the recall.   A complete list of the recalled products along with product codes, descriptions and production dates was available from the Menu Foods Web site, http://www.menufoods.com/recall.   Menu Foods' chief executive and president Paul Henderson told the Associated Press on Friday that the company was still trying to figure out what happened.   He said that the company had received an undisclosed number of owner complaints that dogs and cats were vomiting and suffering kidney failure after eating its products.   The recall covers the company's "cuts and gravy" style food, which consists of chunks of meat in gravy, sold in cans and small foil pouches from Dec. 3 to March 6.   In Omaha, Neb., Susan Balvanz said she sometimes feeds her five cats packets of sliced meat and gravy sold by Nutro Products, one of the brands affected.   "I've done so much research on pet food. It didn't surprise me but it scared me all the same," said Balvanz.   She said her 9-year-old cat, Boots, was especially fond of the food but seemed to have lost its appetite in the last few days.   At the Missouri Valley Veterinary Clinic in Bismarck, N.D., veterinarian Jacob Carlson has been referring worried pet owners to the Menu Foods Web site.   "We've had a lot of calls," Carlson said, although none of his patients were sick.   The company said it makes pet food for 17 of the top 20 North American retailers. It is also a contract manufacturer for the top branded pet food companies, including Procter & Gamble Co. (PG).     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 16:30 ET (20:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Altria Mulls Response To Imperial's Move For Altadis - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Altria (MO), the U.S. company that owns the Philip Morris cigarette brands, is looking at whether to intervene in Imperial Tobacco's (ITY) GBP8 billion bid for Altadis SA (ALT.MC), The Financial Times reports Saturday, citing people familiar with the situation.   The paper says it was unclear late Friday whether Altria would make a rival bid for Altadis or would pounce on Imperial before it became too big as a result of buying the French-Spanish maker of Gauloises cigarettes.   It reports people familiar with the situation saying that Altria was "looking hard" at the situation.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 06:37 ET (10:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: FOCUS: Saudi Arabia May Reap $6B From Cell License This Week
Story: By Majdoline Hatoum     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     DUBAI (Zawya Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabia, the last significantly untapped cell phone market in the Arab world, could net a hefty $6 billion from its latest telecom licensing round this week, analysts say, as nine consortia slug it out to become the kingdom's third operator.   Saudi Arabia, which boasts the second-largest population in the Arab world behind Egypt and enjoyed a petrodollar-fuelled domestic growth rate of more than 12% last year, has the potential to double its cell phone penetration, industry experts believe. This justifies companies paying twice as much for the license as its estimated fair value.   "The Saudi license is the last tempting one in the region," Andrawes Snobar of Jordan-based Arab Advisors Group says.   The kingdom's Communication and Information Technology Commission, which says it wants to challenge the current cell phone duopoly, is expected to announce the winner later this week, though it isn't clear when.   Ibrahim Al Kadi, a senior official at the Commission, told Zawya Dow Jones last week that the consortia "wouldn't be putting their money on the table unless they are seeing a big opportunity."       Plenty Of Growth Left     The consortia are led by companies that include Egypt's Orascom Telecom (ORTE.CI), Kuwait's Mobile Telecom Co. (MTC) and South Africa's MTN Group (MTN.JO).   "The buzz in the market is that the third telecom license could net as much as $6 billion," Wael Ziada, senior telecom analyst at EFG Hermes, says.   "It is a fairly large figure," he adds, but if any market is worth it among the six-member regional Gulf Cooperation Council then it is Saudi Arabia, with cell phone use at around 60% of its potential customer base.   "This is a huge growth potential compared to other GCC countries where the penetration level ranges between 95% to 120%," Ziada says. "So if the Saudi license ends up going for $6 billion, we won't be surprised."   MTC's Managing Director Saad Al Barrak recently told Zawya Dow Jones that the winning bid "will definitely have to be above $5 billion."   Taking into account what Abu Dhabi-based Etisalat paid last year for a license in Egypt, the Saudi license "should be $11 billion," al-Barrak added.   The kingdom's market is, according to its Commission, the highest telecoms revenue generator in the region, with more than $2 billion in fixed-line revenue and over $6 billion from the mobile sector in 2005.   "Such figures guarantee we will see a heated competition on the license," Mark Hammoud of Shuaa Capital says. "Huge operators like Orascom and MTC really want it."   The figure is way above the license's fair value, Arab Advisors' Snobar says.   "According to our own estimation, the license's fair value is a little less than $3 billion."   Therefore, the $6 billion figure being touted "would be a staggering figure that largely exceeds its fair value," Hammoud notes. "But these companies are willing to go that high."   The industry measure of average revenue from each customer is $35 a month in Saudi Arabia, "relatively high given the size of the population and the market's prospects," Hammoud adds.   This contrasts with$21 a user from South Africa's MTN, $14 from Orascom in Egypt, and $11 from China Mobile (0941.HK) in its home territory.   Snobar highlighted ballooning license values in the region.   "We saw it happen in a market like Egypt, where Etisalat paid about $3 billion for a market that isn't one tenth as rich as the Saudi market."   Saudi Arabia currently has two cell phone operators, Saudi Telecommunication Co. and Etihad Etisalat (7020.SA), or Mobily, which broke STC's monopoly two years ago following intense competition from rival bidders.   The second license cost Etisalat 12.2 billion Saudi riyals, or $3.25 billion.   -By Majdoline Hatoum, Dow Jones Newswires; +9714-223-1134; majdoline.hatoum@dowjones.com   Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 05:46 ET (09:46 GMT)

Headline: CBOT To Evaluate Surprise Bid From The ICE - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Directors from the Chicago Board of Trade will meet Tuesday to evaluate the surprise counterbid launched Thursday by the Intercontinental Exchange, though officials are yet to decide whether to open their books to the suitor, reports the Financial Times Saturday, citing sources close to CBOT.   The paper reports the unsolicited all-stock bid from the ICE came just three weeks before CBOT members were due to vote on an agreed merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which has so far declined to comment on whether it will sweeten its own bid with more cash.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 07:16 ET (11:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: First Disney Franchise Store Opens In India
Story: NEW DELHI (AP)--The first Walt Disney franchise store opened in India on Saturday, officials from Disney's local partners said, giving the company its first foothold in India's lucrative retail market.   The store, which sells Walt Disney Co.'s (DIS) branded stationery products under the name "Disney Artist," opened in Gurgaon, a suburb of New Delhi, said Arjun Verma, chief financial officer of Devyani International Ltd.   In October, Disney announced the tie-up with India's RJ Corp. to enter the local market. Devyani International is a subsidiary of RJ Corp.   The partnership is part of Disney's efforts to boost its presence in India, where rising middle-class incomes are driving demand for branded products from the West.   "There is a lot of potential for retailing the Disney brands, which are not currently available in India," Verma told The Associated Press, adding that they planned to set up 150 outlets over the next three years.   "Right now we are just going to concentrate on the stationery but other things may follow," Verma said.   Multinational companies have been eager to grab a share of India's retail market, estimated at about $200 billion a year.   But it is currently dominated by more than 12 million mom-and-pop shops and the government has been slow in opening the market up, partly to protect them.   Last year, the government said it would allow foreign companies to invest in retail stores for single-brand products in partnership with Indian companies.   Several international brands such as Nokia, Marks & Spencer and Adidas have since moved to set up their own stores. Previously, their products were sold through franchises.   However, multi-product retail companies such as Wal-Mart Stores Inc. are still barred from opening stores in India.   Selling through company-owned stores currently totals just $8 billion.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 09:23 ET (13:23 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Speaking Of Dividends: Small Stocks, Big Payouts
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Small-Caps have been performing well. What's more, they're increasingly rewarding their investors with dividends. And Standard & Poor's has noticed.   S&P recently surveyed its SmallCap 600 group for dividend-paying stocks that carry a STARS ranking of four or five. These rankings indicate that S&P analysts expect them to generate superior returns over the next 12 months, as measured by the firm's Stock Appreciation Ranking System. (Four stars mean a stock is a Buy; five, a Strong Buy.)   The accompanying table is a result of S&P's efforts. Only two of the companies  -- Landstar System (ticker: LSTR) and Movado (MOV) -- get five stars. Among the rest, here are a pair that could be worth a look:   One of North America's largest truckers, Arkansas Best (ABFS) "is expanding into faster-growing segments of the market." S&P expects the company, which has negligible long-term debt and over $5 a share in cash, to earn $4.27 this year and $4.50 next, versus 2006's $3.30.   The health-care facilities owned by Medical Properties Trust (MPW) focus on acute-care and in-patient rehabilitation hospitals. S&P thinks "strong rent coverage and a valuation discount to peers more than offset" the Alabama real-estate investment trust's exposure to changes in government reimbursement policies. In 2006, Medical Properties delivered 80% revenue growth and a 30% gain in funds from operations (FFO), an important metric for REITs. The trust's dividend yield is 7.3%; health-care REITs' average is 5.5%.   Will hefty one-time special dividends be the wave of the future? Robert Willens, a Lehman Brothers managing director and tax-accounting expert, thinks they could be over the next few months. He says that companies fear that the 15% tax rate on qualified dividends won't last much longer, and they're eager to have their investors take advantage of what might prove to be a fleeting benefit.   Back in January, Health Management Associates (HMA) voted a $10-a-share bonus, worth $2.4 billion, which was paid March 1. Willens describes this as a "self-LBO" (leveraged buyout), with the company recapitalizing its balance sheet via the issuance of $3.25 billion of new senior secured credit facilities.   In February, General Maritime (GMR), a leading owner and operator of midsize crude-oil tankers, declared a $15 extra, valued at $491 million. According to Willens, that represents more than one-third of the company's market capitalization. It's payable March 23, the record date was March 9 and the ex-date is March 26.   Then, on March 2, dairy giant Dean Foods (DF) also announced a $15 special payout, which will return some $2 billion to its shareholders. The distribution and record dates are April 2 and March 27, and the stock goes ex-dividend April 3. The bonus will be financed by a recapitalization, through $4.8 billion in new senior secured credit facilities.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Indonesia Prosecutors Expect Newmont Unit To Be Found Guilty
Story: JAKARTA (AP)--Indonesian prosecutors are confident a court will find a local subsidiary of Newmont Mining Corp. (NEM) and a top executive guilty of polluting a bay with toxic chemicals when judges announce their verdict in April, a prosecutor said Saturday.   The U.S. gold-mining giant, however, said prosecutors had failed to prove their allegations, and no environmental harm was ever done by Newmont in Buyat Bay, on Indonesia's Sulawesi island.   Prosecutors in November asked judges to sentence Richard Ness - who heads the Denver-based company's Indonesian subsidiary, Newmont Minahasa Raya - to three years in prison if found guilty of contaminating the bay with arsenic and mercury, and to fine Ness and Newmont more than $165,000.   The court was adjourned until April 4 when a panel of judges is scheduled to announce its verdict, presiding judge Ridwan Damanik said Friday of the closely watched case that has been ongoing for 20 months.   "We are optimistic we will win," said prosecutor Purwanta, who like many Indonesians uses one name only. "Many data and facts disclosed in the court have supported our prosecution."   But Ness disagreed. "Buyat Bay is clean, the fish are safe to eat, and our operation did not cause any negative impact to the community," Ness said in a statement Saturday. "The prosecutors have failed to prove their allegations."   Ness said a guilty ruling would contradict several scientific studies that found no evidence of pollution in Buyat Bay.   Some villagers claim they became sick because of pollution, but prosecutors have not presented anyone with serious skin disorders or other illnesses.   A police report showed mercury and arsenic levels in Buyat Bay were well beyond national standards, but tests by the World Health Organization, Indonesian government agencies and several independent groups found that pollutants in the water were within normal limits.   Newmont stopped mining at its Minahasa Raya mine in August 2004 and is spending $5.6 million on reclamation.   In December 2004, Buyat Bay villagers dropped a $543 million civil lawsuit against Newmont, but the Indonesian government later filed a $133 million lawsuit. Newmont settled that case by agreeing to spend $30 million over 10 years on environmental monitoring.   The criminal charges against Ness and Newmont were filed in July 2005.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 03:28 ET (07:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) The Trader: Best Subprime Analogy: Dot-Coms Or Bird Flu?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   For every fear there is a season. in March of 2007, one anxiety above all has the stock market in a clammy, cold sweat --  the fear that economic growth might slow down enough to tip the U.S. into a recession.   All week, traders scrambled to calibrate the fallout from rising mortgage delinquencies, and to gauge how tighter lending would affect the housing market and the economy. A 6.9% pummeling of the Consumer Discretionary SPDR Fund (ticker: XLY) over the past monthpoints to the rising panic about consumer belt-tightening. And on Tuesday, double-whammy reports of drab February retail sales and a surge in late mortgage payments to a 3 1/2-year high spooked investors. Stocks absorbed their second-worst beating of the year.   A midweek bounce off the indexes' early-March low helped contain the carnage. But the fear of slowing growth persists, and its bleak view has increasingly found voice. "Subprime is today's dot-com -- the pin that pricks a much larger bubble" in asset-dependent America, says Morgan Stanley chief economist Stephen Roach. "To me, the real debate is about 'spillovers' -- whether the housing downturn will spread to the rest of the economy."   The Dow Jones Industrial Average suffered its second-biggest weekly drop of the year, closing down 166 points, or 1.4%, to 12,110. It had taken the Dow 82 trading days from its first close above 12,000, on Oct. 19, to its February peak at 12,790 -- and just 15 days to fall back below 12,000, which it briefly did at midweek.   The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell for the third time in four weeks, losing 16 points, or 1.1%, to 1,387. The Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 15, or 0.6%, to 2,373. The Russell 2000 Index of small stocks fell 6, or 0.8%, to 779.   Whether the recent pullback will prove prescient, or become yet another premature over-reaction, remains to be seen. The ferocity of Tuesday's selling -- declining stocks outpaced advancing ones, 10 to 1 -- certainly suggests a vigilant crowd sniffing for the first whiff of trouble.   "That intensity has less to do with the market's fundamentals than its mindset -- the mindset of a market looking for a crisis," says James Paulsen, Wells Capital Management's chief investment strategist. He ticked off a litany of "crises" that had menaced the economy since this bull market began, including the Iraq war, the jobless recovery in 2003, interest-rate hikes that began in 2004, the bird-flu scare, the oil-price surge, Hurricane Katrina, the 2006 inflation scare, the flat-yield curve and, now, the subprime spill. "Each time, caution has persisted, and that has allowed the bull run to persist," he says.   While the housing and auto segments contracted by an alarming 10% last year, these make up 9% of real gross domestic product. The rest of the economy expanded 4.3% in 2006. "For widespread fears of continued economic weakness to prove correct, both housing and autos will need to keep collapsing this year," Paulsen says.   Will the housing market find its feet soon enough to avoid tripping up the economy? Net flow into mutual funds points to a guarded willingness to take a benign view. Solid earning reports from Goldman Sachs (GS) and Lehman Brothers (LEH), covering fiscal quarters that ended before late February, also helped soothe frayed nerves and buttress hopes that the subprime fallout remains contained -- for now.   A surprise $9.9 billion bid by the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) to merge with the Chicago Board of Trade (BOT), which is itself planning to merge with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME), raised the specter of a bidding war and propped up the financial sector. Meanwhile, bullish call trading in Williams- Sonoma (WSM) -- amid speculation it might put itself up for sale -- reminded traders that fear can't expect to have the stage all to itself.   Today, the S&P 500 is more than 4% off its Feb. 22 high, but a measure of net advancing stocks at the New York Stock Exchange had repaired to within 1% of its February peak. Such strong breadth bodes well for the market's long-term uptrend, says Natexis Bleichroeder technical analyst John Roque.   On the other hand, the 10-day average of new highs at the NYSE and Nasdaq had peaked on Feb. 14 at 466, and had since dwindled to 92 -- low, but nowhere near recent oversold readings of about 47. "New highs must rise and new lows must collapse for long-only investors to regain control," Roque says. "Until then, it's our take that the market's corrective phase is not yet over."   How long might the market stay in flux? "To get closure on the current growth scare, we need to see the markets quickly price in recession risk or we have to manage to avert one," notes Merrill Lynch economist David Rosenberg.   Among the signs of capitulation to watch for: a sharp bearish turn in investor sentiment, a big jump in the VIX volatility index to about 30 (it has hovered at 15 to 20 recently), and a flight to bonds that sends the yield of 10-year Treasuries down to 4% (the yield is now near 4.5%). Fed futures have also priced in just one rate cut by August, and last week's uptick in consumer and producer prices could keep the central bank focused on fighting inflation. "A move to price in three rate cuts by then would be a cathartic event for the equity market," Rosenberg says.   While mortgage lenders have been mauled recently, a spirited midweek bounce encouraged bargain hunters hoping that the worst is over. After all, as the bullish case goes, stricter standards will make new loans less rickety, and surviving lenders will pick up market share from the vanquished.   Susceptible lenders on a short list flagged here on Feb. 26 have since fallen hard, and stocks like Fremont General (FMT), Novastar Financial (NFI), Accredited Home Lenders (LEND) and New Century (NEWC) have recently lost more than half their value.   But if mortgage lenders are nearer a bottom, it may be a while before their financial prospects brighten. For instance, data from the Mortgage Bankers Association shows rising delinquencies last quarter in prime-quality adjustable-rate mortgages once low teaser rates were nudged up.   "It's not just an issue of prime versus subprime," says Banc of America Securities analyst Robert Lacoursiere, but the array of "products that financed marginal buyers late in the real-estate cycle." Given the proliferation of such loans, "what we saw was just the first stage of a widely anticipated tightening, but we have not seen the completion of it," he says.   Lacoursiere thinks it's "increasingly likely" the deterioration will spread from subprime to "Alt-A" (which are lower than prime but better than subprime), Option ARMs, "piggyback" and interest-only loans. Lenders relying on "payment stretching" to goose growth will have trouble drumming up new loans, while those dependent on wholesale or indirect channels remain vulnerable to eroding credit quality. Stay wary, also, of lenders with sudden market share gains late in the cycle, since that may indicate slackened standards.   Compared with their peers, Indymac Bancorp (NDE) and Downey Financial (DSL), for example, have suffered a less severe beating given their limited subprime portfolios. Deposits make up 42% of Indymac's funding and a liquidity crunch isn't among the fears. But downside risks remain -- especially if the rot spreads to Alt-A loans, which make up 77% of Indymac's 2006 origination mix, or options ARMs, which account for 54% of Downey's. Countrywide Financial (CFC), where insider stock sales this quarter reached a five-year peak, also could face headwinds if defaults rise in the option ARMs that make up 42% of its loan portfolio. Keefe Bruyette Woods analyst Frederick Cannon says Countrywide is "positioned to survive, but certainly not thrive until the downward spiral in mortgage credit ends."   In a credit down cycle, however, Freddie Mac (FRE) and Fannie Mae (FNM) may provide some shelter, Lacoursiere says. For one thing, these government-sponsored mortgage-finance companies are less exposed to the credit risk of non-traditional mortgages. As yields rise with tightening credit, their cost of funding may not rachet up as much given their implicit government backing, allowing them to lock in wider spreads in a challenging credit environment.   Shockwaves from the epicenter of the quaking mortgage world will shake homebuilders. Although subprime loans make up just a fraction of all mortgages, any tightening of lending standards could crimp home demand and prices, and delay the already-slow convalescence of the ailing housing market.   A recent suggestion to bet on the relative underperformance of homebuilders has already worked out well (see "The Trader," Feb. 12), with the S&P Homebuilders SPDR Fund (XHB) falling 10.3% since, or three times the broad market's decline. More weakness could lie ahead, with mortgage lenders growing guarded just as the spring home sale season arrives. Goldman Sachs, for instance, recently lowered the odds for a better-than-expected spring selling season to 10% from 20%.   At some point, slip-sliding homebuilders may be worth buying again. A number of these stocks are trading just 10% to 20% above their tangible book value, historically a turning point for slipping shares. Certainly, impatient bulls not content to wait for stocks to reach that traditional buy signal might sell out-of-the-money puts now with strike prices set at or below the stocks' tangible book value, as Citigroup's strategists suggested in a midweek note to clients. The put seller commits to buy shares when they fall below certain targets, but the premiums earned are as rich as mortgage worries are rife.   Not all homebuilders will fare equally as lending constricts. Toll Brothers (TOL) and KB Homes (KBH) are highly correlated stocks that have traded in sync 86% of the time over the past year. But Michael Benhamou, Louis Capital's London-based managing partner, sees a possible divergence ahead.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Reliance Industries Eyes Sainsbury, Carrefour -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--India's largest private sector group, Reliance Industries (500325.BY), says it is "taking a look" at stakes in Sainsbury (SBRY.LN) and Carrefour (12017.FR), the Financial Times reports Saturday citing an "insider" at Reliance.   "With both of these companies, we'd definitely get a good supply chain and we would benefit from their experience," the paper reports the person at Reliance saying.   The paper also says Robert Tchenguiz, the property entrepreneur, has said he has raised his Sainsbury stake from 3.47% to 3.95%.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 07:42 ET (11:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Energy's Respite Won't Last Too Much Longer
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra Defotis   Interview With John Segner   Portfolio Manager, AIM Energy Fund     Most energy investors found their returns flickering last year as oil prices finally sagged. But John Segner, the well-respected portfolio manager who runs the AIM Energy Fund, still eked out a nearly 10% return. That's not too surprising since Segner's nearly 17% average annual return in the decade he's managed the fund (first for Invesco and, more recently, AIM) ranks among the top 11% of all natural-resource vehicles. In 2006, giant integrated exploration and refining stalwarts helped power his gains.   Segner thinks that 2007 could be another flat year for oil prices, though he's confident that demand from China, combined with the difficulties of replacing production worldwide, should push prices and energy stocks higher in 2008. Right now, Aim Energy (ticker: FSTEX) is betting on a rebound from some of big oil's weaker performers. He also thinks that nuclear plants are a necessary evil worthy of consideration and is a fan of a few domestic natural-gas plays. Finally, he remains a bull on the U.S. oilfield-services companies whose headquarters dot the skyline near his Houston office. For specifics, read on.     Barron's: Is it all roses for the energy sector?   Segner: I think the natural-gas and oil markets are going to be tightening up -- 2008 and 2009 are going to be good years to be invested in energy. There are a lot of people who think energy stocks, with contracted multiples, won't perform as well, that the run is over, that we have found all the supply we need to meet demand. I think this is a brief pause in the energy shortage, with some production growth in 2007. I don't think in 2008 and 2009 we will have that situation. People are underestimating demand and overestimating supplies.     Q: Where would the new supply come from?   A: I really don't see a lot of non-OPEC production growth. Everything else is going to be dependent upon the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries being able to increase production. There will be some [rise] certainly out of Saudi Arabia, but are Venezuela, Nigeria, Iran or Iraq really going to increase their capacity? It's hard to say they are. This year, the world is going to use about 86 million barrels of oil per day. And if every oil well in the world were running, assuming 1.2% production growth, we are producing around 88 million barrels a day. Reserves that we are putting on, in general, don't produce as fast as the reserves we are replacing.     Q: What if the economies of China or India slow?   A: They may slow, but from a double-digit level to something that is still very high. There are really not signs of that. I just think that there's going to be a lot of support for crude-oil prices, even if the economies of the world are slowing, and I'm not sure they are. The chance of demand going down for energy is remote to none.     Q: What in your portfolio surprised you the most in the past 12 months?   A: Bill Barrett [ticker: BBG] was our worst-performing name, down about 15% in 2006. It's a small-cap. They are exclusively a Rocky Mountain natural-gas play. It's actually a name that I still like very much. They announced fantastic earnings and they are really beginning to show their growth potential.     Q: What went wrong with the stock last year?   A: Mostly people were real negative on natural gas. Last year, we had all the natural gas we needed, storage was up and the price was down. We are going to end this winter with natural-gas storage above normal, but less than we had last year. One reason I am positive on natural gas and Bill Barrett is that we are going to have less imports from Canada and from the Gulf of Mexico. And that may not be clear to people in March and April. Since late September 2006, natural-gas prices have doubled, though Rocky Mountain gas trades at a discount, owing to transmission shortcomings that a new pipeline should remedy within two years.     Q: Are there any other natural-gas plays you like?   A: Southwestern Energy [SWN], a U.S. natural-gas exploration and production company. They have the largest land position in the Fayetteville Shale in northwest Arkansas, an unconventional gas position and one of the few U.S. natural-gas growth areas. That's why we like them; they are a longer-term play. We feel this stock will add a significant value per share in the next five years with more natural-gas production at a low cost. In the past year, it has been trading between 30 and 40, and we think, longer-term, it will trade significantly higher. It is trading at 16 times 2008 earnings, but we think earnings will go up.     Q: How do the demands of national oil companies impact your portfolio?   A: Obviously, there's a higher risk that they could take more profits [from private companies]. One name not in our portfolio --  though it's a very cheap stock and I may just buy it anyway -- is ConocoPhillips [COP]. They had the highest leverage per share of any of the major oil companies in Venezuela, where [President Hugo] Chavez wants a bigger share, and we have stayed away for the past nine months or so. I'm actually warming up to the stock. How much further can it go down? The stock sells at seven times earnings.     Q: Why did some of the biggest integrated oil companies in your portfolio sell off?   A: We were up around 10% last year. It wasn't an awful year, but the honest-to-God truth was that most of our performance in energy last year was in those big-cap names. Chevron [CVX] was a very good performer. Total [TOT] was a reasonably good performer. ExxonMobil [XOM] was absolutely spectacular. It was up 40%, including dividends. Exxon is a fantastic company. There's not a thing wrong with them. They have growth whereas most of the [majors] don't have it.     Q: Why does Wall Street think Exxon earnings will be flat in 2008?   A: Because they are probably using a pretty flat oil price, which we might have. You know, I am not overly bullish for 2007. I'm more bullish as we get to 2008 and 2009. Every year this decade, most analysts have expected earnings declines for this group, and they've been wrong. Exxon, we've got to remember, is a very big chemical producer in the world, and if economies are slowing, that would affect Exxon. However, Exxon has had a way of mitigating that very well over the years. I love the company, to be honest. I don't think Exxon is going to be up 40% this year. And we've taken some profits, but it's still a major holding.     Q: Has hedge-fund interest in commodities changed the predictability of your investments?   A: Hard to say. There is more volatility. I will tell you one thing that has surprised me. Let's just take the big market drop earlier this month. I don't think I have ever seen a day where the market was down 3.5% and Exxon was down 4.7%. Usually, Exxon was the best-performing name on a bad market day, no matter what. I don't know if it was hedge funds, derivatives, [exchange-traded funds] or what, but that was unusual. It was nothing company-specific that I could see that would cause it.     Q: What about Brazil's oil producer, Petrobras?   A: We bought Petrobras (Petroleo Brasileiro) last September at six times earnings. We bought it in the 70s. The stock got up to 107, but it has corrected pretty hard here -- down about 17%. Petrobras [PBR] actually has one of the best growth profiles of any of the major oil companies. I do consider it a major oil company. They are expanding. Most of their production is oil, in Brazil, but they are also expanding fairly aggressively into the Gulf of Mexico.     Q: The Gulf's deep water?   A: Yes, and Petrobras has had some success doing that. The stock is listed in New York and the company uses U.S. accounting rules. I think that helps us on the risk profile. But here again, this is a company that is so cheap. It has grown [in] double digits. Other major oil companies can't say that. I'm opportunistic in adding to it, and we may be approaching a point where that will look good. I do recognize the developing-country risk. It's going to sell at a discount because the government does still own the majority of the shares. I think all that's pretty much discounted in the stock.     Q: You own a fair number of American oilfield services companies.   A: Our portfolio is approximately 30% to 40% oil services. Actually most of them are headquartered [here] in Houston --  one of our advantages -- but their revenues and earnings are international. The international and government producers are spending so much money to increase capacity and a lot of that is flowing to oil-service companies. The stock multiples have contracted over the past year; the stocks are actually cheaper than they were a year ago, and yet the earnings still are increasing. Rarely have I seen a period where oil-service names sell at a discount to the S&P 500...with 14% earnings growth.     Q: Is there a name in oilfield services that you especially like?   A: Our biggest holding in that group is National Oilwell Varco [NOV]. It's the world's largest supplier of oilfield rigs and rig equipment. As new rigs are re-equipped or new ones are built, National Oilwell is going to be the supplier of much of that equipment. Their backlog is going up, and it is likely to increase. The stock was trading at about 60 last March and today it is at 67 [it's since jumped above 74, near its 52-week high]. They just blew through earnings numbers and everyone seems a little surprised. It's a name that I think is still going to do very, very well going forward. Grant Prideco [GRP] looks pretty cheap at about 10 times earnings for 2007. And estimates are too low on the Street. We also happen to like Schlumberger [SLB]. Schlumberger has a lot of international focus. That is where a lot of the spending is being done. We think Schlumberger will continue to be a good stock through this decade. It is trading at 16 times 2007 earnings. It always sold at a premium. I am not overly concerned about it.     Q: What about alternative energy?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Saudi Telecom Regulator Qualifies 7 Bids For License
Story: (Update with more information on the consortia, officials quotes, and analysis)     RIYADH (Zawya Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabia's telecom regulator announced Saturday it has qualified seven of nine consortia that submitted their bids for the third Saudi public mobile services license, the Communications and Information Technology Commission said.   Saudi Arabia already has two public mobile services providers - Saudi Telecom Company (7010.SA) and Etihad Etisalat (7020.SA).   The two disqualified consortia were an Egyptian Orascom Telecom (ORTE.CI)-led consortium and an Indian MTNL-led consortium, Al Shoula.    In a statement issued Saturday, CITC said the evaluation for the technical and commercial bids resulted in qualifying seven of the nine applications - the Kuwaiti MTC (MTC) and partners consortium; Samawat Consortium, led by the Indian Bharti Co.; Dubai-based Oger Telecom; a consortium led by Kingdom Holding, with Turkcell; Tawasul Consortium, led by the Caribbean operator Digicell, with Saudi Injaz Projects; the South African MTN (MTN.JO) consortium; and a consortium of Abdullah Abdulaziz Al Rajhi with Reliance Communication.   The governor of CITC, Dr. Mohammed Al-Suwaiyel, indicated the selection phase will consist of opening the single sealed financial proposal of each eligible applicant at a public opening ceremony March 24, at the CITC headquarters in Riyadh .   With the fact that a number of the wealthiest regional and international businessmen are among bidders, including Saudi billionaire Alwaleed Bin Talal, chairman of Kingdom Holding Co.,  the late Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri's family through Oger Telecom, Irish billionaire Denis O'Brien through the Caribbean Digicell,  and Saudi billionaire Abdullah Al Rajhi, observers are expecting a tough financial competition.   "We are not subject to rumors. We believe the Saudi market is one of the best in the region with potential annual growth at 3.5%" said Talal Al Maiman, director for development and local investment at Kingdom Holding.   He told Zawya Dow Jones his KHC and its sister companies will own 35% of the Kingdom-Turkcel consortium, and 15% will go to the Turkish company, while 40% will be floated into the Saudi stock market, and 10% will be split between the Public Pension Agency and the General Organization for Social Insurance.   However analysts expected  the Saudi government may receive as much as $6 billion from the sale of the third mobile license.   "The buzz in the market is that the third telecom license could net as much as $6 billion," Wael Ziada, senior telecom analyst at EFG Hermes, says.   "It is a fairly large figure," he adds, but if any market is worth it among the six-member regional Gulf Cooperation Council then it is Saudi Arabia, with cell phone use at around 60% of its potential customer base.   "This is a huge growth potential compared to other GCC countries where the penetration level ranges between 95% to 120%," Ziada says. "So if the Saudi license ends up going for $6 billion, we won't be surprised."   MTC's Managing Director Saad Al Barrak recently told Zawya Dow Jones that the winning bid "will definitely have to be above $5 billion."   However Andrawes Snobar of Jordan-based Arab Advisors Group says the $6 billion figure is way above the license's fair value.   "According to our own estimation, the license's fair value is a little less than $3 billion." Andrawes has said.     -By Anees Al Qudaihi, Majdoline Hatoum, Dow Jones Newswires; +966 1 291 4872; anees.alqudaihi@dowjones.com     Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 16:02 ET (20:02 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Finally, Airborne And Ready To Soar
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Its backlog alone provides a lot of thrust for Textron shares. With customers plunking down $250,000 deposits for business jets that won't arrive until 2010, the aircraft maker doesn't have to do much more than deliver those orders to lift its profits over the next five years.   Since the king of go-go era conglomerates began narrowing its focus to jets and helicopters under chief executive Lewis Campbell, demand for flying machines has gone Textron's way. Business folk around the world want the company's thrifty midsize jets to avoid the hassles of commercial flights. Its Bell helicopters are making bee-lines to the world's disasters -- natural and man-made. Even its controversial vertical-takeoff troop carrier, the V-22 Osprey, will be deployed to Iraq this year, after decades in development. Campbell proudly notes that Textron shares (Ticker: TXT) have doubled in the past five years, to a recent 89.52. They could double again over the next five.   In the late 1980s, Textron got 56% of its sales from various aircraft, automotive, industrial and financial divisions. But last year Cessna and Bell aircraft accounted for 66% of $11.5 billion in revenue and 71% of the $706 million in earnings ($5.43 a share) pulled in by the Providence, R.I., company. Textron still runs other businesses: golf carts, grounds-keeping machines, fuel tanks, power tools, pumps. And a finance unit lends money to their customers. But Campbell insists that his managers demonstrate how their groups will raise future returns, and therefore their present value to shareholders. If a business doesn't look like it can, Textron sells it -- last year, it booted its unprofitable riveting systems business.   Sales grew 18% in 2006 at the Bell helicopter unit to $3.4 billion, but earnings fell 32%, as it wrestled with cost overruns to upgrade the Marine Corps' Huey and Cobra helicopters. So in January, Bell got a new boss. Profits have a good chance of improving, because the Marines finally have accepted the first of the upgraded copters. That will let Bell focus on streamlining production of the 280 copters it will deliver over the next 13 years.   Another Bell aircraft that's finally taking off is the V-22 Osprey, a personnel transport craft that ascends vertically and then tilts its rotors forward to fly as fast as an airplane. The V-22 program has had to overcome deadly crashes, ballooning costs and even a cancellation back when Dick Cheney was defense secretary. But the first squadron is expected to fly this summer.   At about $70 million the V-22 is an expensive bird. So even though current government plans call for the purchase of 360 for the Marines, 50 for Air Force special operations and 48 for the Navy, there are doubts that all 458 orders will materialize over the 15-year course of the program. If the craft works wonderfully, however, and the military finds itself fighting many battles beyond the range of traditional helicopters, then Bell might get enough orders to trim V-22 production costs. In any event, Campbell expects the V-22 to be generating $1 billion in annual revenue in a few years.   Bell is also seeing unprecedented demand for its commercial helicopters. Oil and gas drillers, public-safety agencies and passenger services have increased their orders. Textron financial chief Ted French can't recall when the company last enjoyed a backlog for its commercial copters. "We have not had this kind of future growth visibility in our business forever," he says.   Thanks largely to the Bell and the Cessna aircraft units, Textron's backlog at year-end 2006 hit a record $13.4 billion. About $8.5 billion was for Cessna, impressive for a business with just under $4.2 billion in sales last year. Its new Citation CJ4 jet, not due for delivery until 2010, already has $1 billion in orders.   Several factors are powering business aviation. Companies are replacing the first generation of business jets, created in the 1970s, with cheaper-to-operate craft like Cessna's Citations. Commercial airline delays and government security screens aren't going away. And schemes like fractional ownership have made jets more affordable. About $1.4 billion of Cessna's year-end backlog was from a fractional jet client.   International customers have also become bigger buyers. Less than 20% of Cessna orders came from outside the U.S. in 2002, notes Cessna chief Jack Pelton. But this year, international orders should kick in 48% of revenue.   Cessna, which has outspent rivals on new-product development, is growing sales at nearly a 20% rate, but it's doing so efficiently. Campbell demands that his technocrats employ "six-sigma" quality controls and "lean manufacturing" techniques. He approvingly notes that Cessna delivered about the same number of jets in 2006 as it did in the previous peak year of 2001 -- around 310  -- but with twice the return on capital. Campbell, we should note, is also a director of Barron's publisher, Dow Jones.   Jerry Senser, co-chief investment officer at Institutional Capital, says his firm thinks Textron could add at least a buck a share in earnings over each of the next five years, boosting them from above $6 this year to $10 by 2011. At a reasonable multiple of 17.5 times earnings, Textron shares would double in that stretch. His firm owned over 3 million shares at year-end 2006.   If Textron has truly risen above the previous problems of its military-helicopter programs, there's no reason why its shares shouldn't fly.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) The Striking Price: Let's Hear It For Fear!
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Options prices in the financial sector remain rich, as stock investors relentlessly continue to buy defensive puts in case the subprime-mortgage debacle offers up another big surprise that shakes the market.   Defensive put buying is helping to keep implied volatility elevated across the group, even as the options market's fear gauge, the Chicago Board Options Exchange's Market Volatility Index (VIX), has retreated from recent highs as major stock indexes have rebounded from lower levels.   The dislocation between many stock and option prices reflects the fact that implied volatility is heavily influenced by put buying, and many aggressive traders and investors continue to sell puts against stocks they'd like to own.   "Enormous put buying, premium pick-up and fear reflected in the financials! Opportunities abound." That's how Miller Tabak's options strategists summed up the sector in a trading advisory sent late in the week to their clients, who include many hedge funds and institutional investors.   To be sure, there may not be enough available data to assuage the concerns of risk-averse portfolio managers with substantial financial-sector exposure, but there is enough information for aggressive traders to conclude that they have a pretty good chance to make money by "selling fear."   As hackneyed as that phrase has become, selling fear has become a reflexive strategy in the options market, where experience has taught many traders that profits are made when the crowd is too negative or too enthusiastic about stocks.   Contrarian traders are increasingly narrowing their focus on the financial sector. They're selling expensive puts against pedigreed stocks like Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), Bear Stearns (BSC), Lehman Brothers (LEH) and Wells Fargo (WFC), essentially betting that the worst is over.   Options prices are also elevated in mortgage insurers, such as Radian Group (RDN), MBIA (MBI) and PMI Group (PMI), but it is likely prudent for all but the most aggressive traders to limit their risk and stick with diversified, blue-chip financials, or even securities that track the sector. Stick with the singles and doubles; don't go for the triples and home runs. Indeed, the Select Sector Financial SPDR (XLF) has emerged as a favorite of hedge funds and institutional traders because it delivers the group in a liquid product that is easily bought or sold, regardless of market conditions.   Despite the aggressiveness of put sellers, some are evolving their technique. They are increasingly converting short put trades into spreads, effectively selling high volatility and then buying a put that will increase in value should the underlying stock fall in the near term.   The prospect of another decline should be a clarion call for investors to consider selling three-month calls against existing positions. Market sophisticates will sneer at this suggestion because buy-writes limit upside profit potential in a rising market. They're right, of course.   But doesn't capping the upside some of the time in some percentage of the portfolio seem reasonable now?   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Energy's Respite Won't Last Too -2-
Story: A: There are going to be individual names that will eventually be winners. We are warming up to them. If they are a real business. If they are cheap. I'm hearing, "Green is good business." But if it's just, "Green is good PR," then I have a problem with it. BP [BP] is a holding of ours, and it's also the largest developer of solar out there. It's also very big in other alternatives.     Q: How does liquefied natural gas fit in?   A: Cheniere Energy (LNG) is the purest play on LNG around and liquefied natural gas is one of the big alternatives out there. A lot of people don't realize it. We are going to have to import more natural gas, and Cheniere got way ahead of the competition, scouting locations five to seven years ago. Cheniere has four locations, all here on the coast of Texas and Louisiana, where they are building LNG receiving facilities. I visited one recently and was very impressed. If we are going to talk about greenhouse emissions, natural-gas produces a third of the carbon dioxide emissions produced by coal and half of what crude oil produces. And clearly hydrogen for fuel cells will come from natural gas, [although] a lot of people think it will come from water, a more expensive proposition.     Q: What do you think about the proposed buyout of TXU, the Texas utility?   A: TXU was our biggest holding in the AIM Utilities Fund (FSTUX), which I also run. I was hoping for a significantly higher bid, but we were a long-term holder of the stock.     Q: So you sold it?   A: I can only talk about holdings through December 2006. Longer-term, we were hoping for a higher valuation over the next two or three years than the roughly $69 offer. The deal is not a slam-dunk, given regulatory approval. The stock is down since the offer.   Meanwhile, TXU won't build some coal-fired plants that were on the drawing board.   Texas is one of the fastest-growing states in the Union and, whether we are going to get the electricity from coal or something else, we need to come up with something to build that capacity.     Q: What about nuclear?   A: We have to look at nuclear. We have no choice because nuclear can put out a lot of energy from a small footprint of land and doesn't have any CO2 emissions. It may have a lot of other issues, but it doesn't have carbon dioxide. And the political train on CO2 has already left the station. NRG Energy [NRG] is another name in our utilities fund and it is proposing to build two Texas nuclear plants.   We also own Chicago Bridge & Iron [CBI] in the energy fund. They built nuclear plants in the past and they are working on refinery expansions and LNG receiving facilities. Their backlog has more than doubled in the past year. We have not built any new nuclear plants in the U.S., but I have to think that CBI will be one of the prime candidates. It's going to take two or three years just to get the permits, so it's hard to invest very much into that at the moment. Uranium is something else that we have owned in the portfolio.     Q: There aren't that many uranium plays.   A: There sure aren't. Cameco [CCJ] is probably one of the better ones, and they have a mining problem right now in Canada. Their main new mine is flooded. And 10% of the world's supply of uranium is going to come from that one mine and it's 50% of the uranium production growth in the world. It's going to cost a lot more to get the mine producing and it's going to be delayed.     Q: Is the stock attractive now?   A: I'm not ready to say that until we get an estimate on how much more this is going to cost. Is it going to be $1 billion or is it going to be $3 billion and what is the timing? On the surface, it looks cheap.   If China's growth is strong, but is cut in half, certainly the market is going to react negatively.   On the other hand, how long is that going to last? China is still using only 6.5 million barrels of oil per day. We are using 20 million barrels per day here in the United States. China is 25% of the world population. The Chinese are getting off bicycles. They want air conditioning. They are getting housing. If China slows, it would just be a bump in the road. Oil-demand growth could slow down, but the chance of it going below 86 million barrels, say, next year? I just don't see that happening. And I don't see a lot of capacity growth. Supply-demand is still going to be tight.   Energy is going to do very well. The multiples have been contracting for the better part of 12 months. And we are toward the end of that correction more than we are at the beginning of it.     Q: Thank you, John.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Plugged In: Cisco Might Not Suit WebEx
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Did the right company buy WebEx communications?   Cowan software analyst Peter Goldmacher thinks not. The WebEx bull has long believed the Santa Clara, Calif. software company is under-appreciated, but he's not confident that Cisco Systems is the right fit to realize what he sees as its potential -- becoming an on-demand dynamo for big enterprise-software users.   The ever-acquisitive Cisco (ticker: CSCO) last week announced it agreed to buy WebEx (WEBX), a maker of Web communications and corporate-collaboration software, for $3.2 billion, or $57 a share -- including the company's roughly $300 million in existing cash. That's a 23% premium to WebEx's pre-deal close of 46.20. Shares were trading Friday at 56.61. If approved by both boards, the all-cash deal will close before August, according to Cisco.   "I'm wearing my black arm band," said Goldmacher in mock protest.   That's not to say Goldmacher's clients aren't smiling. If they bought when he started extolling the virtues of WebEx in early January of last year, with the shares at 21.50, the purchase price represents a near-three-bagger. And if Barron's readers acted on his advice following our positive feature story last year ("Why WebEx Will Shine,"June 12, 2006), they would have about doubled their investment.   Handsome proceeds aside, did management do the right thing? It boils down to whether you think WebEx is a "communications" company or a "data" company, Goldmacher asserts. If you prefer it as a communications play, Cisco is a good fit; if you believe that it's an on-demand data supplier, then a large enterprise-software suitor would make a better partner, he argues. Goldmacher contends that 28 times 2007 free cash flow  is a "reasonable" price, but doesn't rule out counter-bids from IBM (IBM), SAP (SAP) or Oracle (ORCL).   "In my mind, it would be much better served being acquired by someone like Oracle," whose salesforce is better suited to sell the subscription service to its existing customers, Goldmacher says.   WebEx is best known as a provider of rich-video-conferencing services over the Internet, but its Web-based collaborative software applications that allow workers to share information simultaneously from different corporate silos could be an enterprise jewel. Cisco says it bought WebEx as a way for the networking giant to reach more small-business customers. But WebEx Chief Executive Subrah Iyar insists that Cisco understands the on-demand potential, too.   "We are not selling (our potential) short," Iyar told Barron's. "They get it."   Cisco Chief Development Officer Charles Giancarlo (who intriguingly announced the deal without CEO John Chambers present) says that WebEx's expected $450 million-plus in sales this year won't boost Cisco earnings for its fiscal year ending June 29. Most analysts don't expect the deal to have much effect on Cisco (CSCO) shares in the near-term, but they see WebEx contributing to the company's efforts to add products and services at the edges of networks. Cisco shares were flat on the day of the deal, and were quoted Friday at 25.82.   Did Oracle or SAP already make a pass? Iyar acknowledged that "software companies" showed interest, but he says Cisco came on strong and "moved fast." In fact, Cisco officials told Iyar that they were going to enter Web-based collaboration either way. "In reality, they will do it with you or without you," Iyar mused.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
