Headline: Barron's(3/19) Follow-Up: Clear Channel s Move May Not Save Deal
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Clear Channel Communications, facing strong investor opposition to a proposed $26 billion leveraged buyout, last week tried to improve the odds for the controversial deal.   The company said it is postponing a scheduled March 21 shareholder vote on the transaction to April 19, to "better align the voting and economic interests of all Clear Channel shareholders."   In reality, the postponement will increase the power of arbitragers and other short-term investors whoare more apt to vote yes, in order to capture the 7% spread between the current share price of $35.25 and the deal price of $37.60. The postponement allows anyone who bought the stock in the past two months to vote. Shareholders of record on March 23 can vote; the old record date was Jan. 22.   The buyout, if approved, could close by year-end. There has been active trading in Clear Channel since late January, with about half the company's 493 million shares (ticker: CCU) changing hands. The postponement may not be enough to swing the proposal, whose prospects have seemed bleak because of opposition from some large shareholders, notably Fidelity Investments, which holds about 10% of Clear Channel stock. ("Why Clear Channel's Buyout May Go Bust," March 5.)   In fact, Clear Channel's bold ploy could further inflame some already disenchanted investors and harden their opposition. "Clear Channel is throwing long-term shareholders under the bus," says one foe of the deal. Detractors argue that the buyout bid significantly undervalues the company and that Clear Channel shares are worth $42 or more.   Clear Channel, the country's largest radio operator, needs approval of two-thirds of its shares outstanding, a high hurdle. Shareholders who don't cast ballots effectively are voting against the deal.   One big stockholder, Highfields Capital Management, the Boston investment firm, lifted its stake to 5% from 3%, according to a filing last week. Highfields won't comment on its position on the buyout, but it is believed to oppose the deal.   The opposition of just a few big shareholders probably will sink the deal, given that an estimated 15% of shareholders may not vote. The percentage of investors who vote on takeovers is rarely above 85%. Just 81% of Eddie Bauer holders, for instance, cast ballots in a February vote on that clothing maker's proposed buyout. The company didn't get the needed majority, as 44% of shareholders voted yes; 37%, no, and 19% didn't cast a ballot.   Last week, Victor Miller, a Bear Stearns analyst who is the Street's most prominent critic of the deal, outlined a scenario in which an independent, public Clear Channel could realize significant value for shareholders through a multi-step process, including a sale of its international billboard business and a spinoff of its domestic billboard operations. He arrived at a value of $44 a share, before further shareholder-friendly actions, including a debt-financed stock buyback.   One reason for the opposition to the deal is the lofty value of Clear Channel's billboard unit, which trades separately as Clear Channel Outdoor (CCO). Clear Channel Communications' 90% stake in Clear Channel Outdoor is worth $8.4 billion, or $17 per Clear Channel Communications share. Clear Channel Outdoor trades around $27, up from $21 in the fall.   Some investors also are upset that Mark Mays, Clear Channel Communications' CEO, and Randall Mays, its president, plan to stay on if the buyout succeeds, with each getting options on 2.5% of the stock of the private company. The buyout is being led by Thomas H. Lee and Bain Capital, two large private-equity firms.   Clear Channel argues the buyout price of $37.60, arrived at after an auction last year, is fair. Deal proponents argue that radio, like other traditional media, faces a tough future. And it doesn't look likely that the buyout group will increase its bid.   Clear Channel may end up being the most important failure of an LBO, as institutional holders dig in and tell Wall Street they're tired of seeing private-equity firms enriched at their expense.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Streetwise: Business As Usual?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   It's all in your head. This is a routine pullback. Stocks are cheap.   This has been Wall Street's line to investors in the weeks since the S&P 500 index was pole-axed from a seven-year high, falling as much as 6.6% last Wednesday.   Let's evaluate.   It's all in your head? Well, yes, to the extent that market prices always have a great deal to do with investor psychology, and swing dramatically on either side of hypothetical "fair value" all the time. A majorchunk of the 20% surge from last July's low to the recent high in the S&P was mere optimism capitalized in stock values.   Investors were contented -- though not wildly giddy -- at the start of the year, as the news was full of affirmation that the ideal economic and liquidity environment was upon us. The mood has since soured. Surveys of individual investors have shown a surge in bearish feelings, but not quite to the degree at the market's low point of last summer.   Joe Mezrich of Nomura Securities says the options market shows that the fear level is elevated but not to levels that preceded the furious rally that began in July. His take: If stocks bottom near current levels, the ensuing rally will probably  not be as rewarding as last year's.   Is this merely a routine pullback? In magnitude, by the standards of the present bull market, the answer is . . . almost. Each of the past three calendar years has witnessed one high-single-digit percentage decline. The 6.6% maximum loss in the S&P lately is not far off.   At some point, such a pattern of manageable dips will be broken, unpleasantly, though it's tough to determine that this is that instance. Note the time factor. Last year, the bottoming process wasn't complete for more than two months; the current selloff began just three weeks ago.   One of the most widely held assertions is that stocks are inexpensive. Yet it depends on what they're being compared to. It's easy to say big stocks are cheap compared to the late 1990s, or to startlingly low corporate-bond yields, but that doesn't advance the discussion very far.   The stocks in the S&P 500 are now trading at 14.8 times forecast earnings for the next 12 months. At last year's low, the index bottomed at 14.5 times expected earnings. Yet, back then, had the market sniffed out that projected earnings could be beaten easily, as they eventually were? At the July low, the S&P traded for 13.8 times the earnings that eventually were reported over the next four quarters.   Maybe -- with overall earnings growth ebbing, financial-company earnings slated to account for an outsized share of total profits and margins already high -- the market is expressing less confidence in Corporate America's ability to keep over-earning versus history.   One of the leading forces in taking companies private may be taking itself public.   Reports emerged Friday that Blackstone Group is preparing to go public, with www.wsj.com citing unnamed sources ballparking a $4 billion initial offering of 10% of the firm. Blackstone wouldn't comment.   On first look, that seems an enormous $40 billion valuation, based on the $55 billion in private-equity, real estate, debt and hedge-fund assets under management. Fortress Investment (FIG), with $30 billion in a roughly comparable mix of businesses, is valued under $11 billion.   We don't know how profitable Blackstone's large corporate-advisory and consulting-services practices are, or precisely how much its private-company holdings are worth.   No doubt a deal, should it happen, would be a hot item, with the new stock trading to an unattractively fat premium instantly, just as Fortress did. That stock opened at 35 after IPO investors paid $18.50, only to drop back into the mid-20s.   Many are asking why Blackstone chief Stephen Schwarzman would reverse his stated anti-IPO position and subject himself to the quarter-by-quarter scrutiny of a public company, which he has decried in the past. Well, Schwarzman and other LBO artists buy average companies which they perceive to be under-managed or misvalued by the public, and retool or leverage them up in private.   One thing's for sure: Schwarzman (he of the $3 million birthday party and Fortune magazine's recently crowned "New King of Wall Street") doesn't consider his company anything near "average," or "under-managed." And he and his partners are probably confident that, like Goldman Sachs (GS), Blackstone can enjoy the rewards of public ownership without ever divulging exactly how its money is made. While the investment climate is strong, that is.   But mustn't this mean the peak of the easy-money craze for financial engineering and ever-larger private buyouts?Probably not. After all, Goldman's IPO didn't mean happy days on Wall Street were about to come to a crashing end. That didn't happen until 10 months later.   ---   E-Mail: Michael.santoli(at)barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Big Wheels Keep On Turning
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Investors in Ryder System have had an uneasy ride of late. After topping 59 in June, shares of the Miami-based truck-leasing and logistics company have fallen to around 49 amid concern that a sluggish economy would dent the truck-freight business and commercial rental operations.   But Ryder (ticker: R) could gain traction later this year, when the economy and freight business are expected to stabilize. The company's contractual business, which provides long-term leaseand maintenance contracts, is likely to accelerate as Ryder recognizes revenue from deals signed last year. And the fast-growing supply-chain business, which sells logistics, distribution and transportation services, could expand at a high single-digits rate, driving earnings growth in the longer term.   "This will be a show-me year in terms of execution," says David Goerz of Highmark Capital Management, which owns 98,000 Ryder shares. He acknowledges that the company could face problems if U.S. gross domestic product grows at a subpar 2%. But with most economists forecasting 2.5% to 3% GDP growth, Goerz says Ryder should have little trouble besting its conservative guidance for 2007: at least a 7% gain in earnings, to $262 million- $268 million, or $4.30 to $4.40 a share, on revenue of up to $6.7 billion. As for its shares, Ryder has "20% upside or better this year," asserts Goerz, implying the stock could rise to around 60.   Founded in 1933, Ryder made its name by renting yellow trucks and vans to furniture-hauling consumers. But the company jettisoned its retail operation and other highly cyclical businesses in the mid-1990s to focus on providing tractor-trailers, vans and logistics services to Hewlett Packard (HPQ), General Motors (GM) and other commercial customers. Ryder lost much of its identity in the transformation, but gained a more predictable business that generated a record $6 billion of revenue last year. It also garnered predictable -- and handsome -- returns for shareholders, returning an average 16% annually for the past five years   "Ninety percent of our business is contractual and therefore less susceptible to the economy," says CEO Greg Swienton. "Large investors get it, but individual investors might not."   That could change, however, if Ryder's revenue grows by 6% to 8% a year, and earnings per share by 10% to 15%, as the company expects. For this year, Swienton is counting on the supply-chain business, which generated 25% of operating revenue and 16% of pre-tax profits last year, to pace revenue growth, with 9% to 10% gains. The company's fleet-management unit, which leases, rents and repairs vehicles and generates about two-thirds of sales, is likely to grow 2% to 4% this year. The contractual business, part of fleet management, could see revenue rise 6%, offsetting an expected 6% to 7% drop in commercial rental. Ryder's smallest segment, contract carriage, chips in 12% of revenue, and could grow by 5% a year.   At 10 times analysts' 2008 earnings estimates of $4.81 a share, Ryder is trading considerably below its historic average price/earnings multiple of 15. As results improve, investors are likely to pay up for this brand leader in the $295 billion global supply-chain-logistics market. "If Ryder can grow EPS at high-single-digit to low-double-digit rates this year, multiple expansion could occur in the second half of 2007, even if the economy lags," says Stephens analyst Alexander Brand, who has an Overweight rating on the stock.   In response to slowing freight demand, the company is reducing its commercial truck fleet by about 13%, and reining in capital spending. That belt-tightening should produce free cash flow of around $235 million this year. Swienton says Ryder might consider snapping up some of its own shares, or making acquisitions with its excess cash. The company boasts a decent balance sheet, with debt equal to 60% of total capital, and pays out 84 cents a share a year, for a dividend yield of 1.7%.   Baird analyst Jon Langenfeld, who raised his price target to 65 from 57 in February, gives management high marks for consolidating operations and displaying pricing discipline. "An attractive and underappreciated part of the story is the progress management has made in improving the core internal operations and improving sales function," he says.   In 2005, Ryder split field managers' responsibilities into sales and operations, which officials say has upped productivity and customer retention while lowering costs.   Skeptics remain, however, as Ryder's current price suggests. Bear Stearns analyst Edward Wolfe thinks that pricing pressure from an oversupply of rental trucks will depress 2007 earnings to $4.25 a share, below the Street's $4.35 consensus. "Ryder has less operating leverage to the economy than most transports, and its revenue and EPS deceleration has lagged," Wolfe says.   Another potential worry: Troubled GM accounts for about 40% of supply-chain revenue. But Toyota also is a big client, and Swienton notes that Ryder is diversifying into   high-tech and fast-moving consumer goods. Besides, in a slow economy, companies could save money by outsourcing more transportation and maintenance work.   You can't rent a Ryder truck anymore, which may disappoint consumers. But growth trends in Ryder's newer, more profitable lines of business are unlikely to disappoint investors.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sainsbury Pension Trustees Ask GBP600M - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The private equity bidders stalking Sainsbury (SBRY.LN) may be forced to pour GBP600 million into the pension fund before they are allowed to bid for the group, the Daily Mail reports Saturday without citing who provided the information.   The paper says it understands the CVC-led consortium, has yet to agree terms with the fund's trustees.   The trustees want to be certain former employees' benefits are guaranteed over the long-term, the paper writes.   The Daily Mail adds, the pension is currently GBP300 million in the red, but trustee chairman John Adshead is expected to demand the bidders pay a lump sum to cancel it out.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.thisismoney.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 08:14 ET (12:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) European Trader: A Sweetener For Cadbury Schweppes
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin   The arrival of activist investor Nelson Peltz on the Cadbury Schweppes shareholder roster has really accelerated change at the U.K. candy and beverage maker.   CEO Todd Stitzer announced Thursday that he would separate the company's confectionery and Americas Beverages units, at an unspecified date. That raises speculation that one or both could eventually be takeover targets. Details of the plan will be disclosed on June 19.   On paper, a breakup has long looked tempting. Apply Coca-Cola's or Pepsico's multiple to Americas Beverages, and Hershey's or Wrigley's to the confectionery operation, and you get a richer valuation for Cadbury, whose stock trades in London under ticker symbol CBRY and whose American depositary shares change hands on the Big Board under ticker CSG.   Indeed, Cadbury has been trading at 19 times estimated 2007 earnings, versus 18 to 22 times for its U.S. rivals, and the 16 average forward multiple that it fetched in 2006, according to InFinancials and FactSet.   But the argument often cited for Cadbury's ditching its U.S. drinks business -- the Sisyphean task of taking on Coke and Pepsi in their home market -- applies to any owner of the Cadbury portfolio, which counts Dr Pepper, 7 Up and Snapple among its better-known brands. Equally, the idea that sodas and candy don't sit easily under the same corporate roof is hard to square with the examples of some of Cadbury's respected peers. Nestle juggles coffee and pet food quite profitably, and Danone does the same with bottled water and yogurt. What counts is the quality of the management.   Stitzer's record has been sullied by a salmonella scare at Cadbury's U.K. chocolate business -- from which sales are yet to recover convincingly -- as well as some clumsy communication with investors. But Stitzer's biggest deal, the $4.2 billion acquisition of Adams, was an inspired move, turning Cadbury into the world's No. 2 chewing-gum producer, behind No. 1 Wrigley.   Cadbury would look more focused without its European beverages unit, and can claim a measure of success in the U.S. drinks market where it gained share in 2006, while improving its control of distribution. Overall, however, the performance of its U.S. drinks business has been mixed.   The company has re-energized Snapple and successfully launched new products like iced teas and energy drinks. But it hasn't been able to revive Dr Pepper and 7 Up, whose popularity is fading. Cadbury's confectionery margins lag well behind those of its European and U.S. peers. And the company's need to invest in new brands and to spend more on marketing to shore up flagging ones rules out any short-term improvement.   That said, with Peltz breathing down his neck, Stitzer was under great pressure to do something. After all, Peltz is the man who revived Snapple before selling it at a fat profit to Cadbury and was the force behind the recent shakeup at Heinz. He knows a thing or two about the food and beverage businesses. He also knows how to boost share prices.   Cadbury ADSs closed at 41.94 on Friday, March 9, the last trading day before news of Peltz's 2.98% stake surfaced. Friday, they were near 48, almost 14% higher, and not far from the 52-to-53 range at which a Wachovia Capital Markets report values all of the company on a sum-of-the-parts basis.   ---   MATTHEW CURTIN, who is based in Paris, is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                      DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country    DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point     Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Barron's(3/19) Follow-Up: Crumbs For New Century Holders?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   By last week, subprime-mortgage lender New Century Financial had become something of a household name -- thanks to overwrought press coverage of its woes. Stories abounded that Century's liquidity problems might not only pancake the $1 trillion subprime market, but also batter the U.S. and global economies. Bears hinted that its demise might rival Vienna's Creditanstalt in 1931, which deepened the Great Depression.   The news is indeed ugly for New Century shareholders, but it's no surprise to Barron's readers. More than two years ago ("No Margin of Safety," Oct. 11, 2004), we looked at New Century with a jaundiced view. We pointed out its over-dependence on Wall Street financing both to make mortgages and to sell them to securitizers. New Century had nearly succumbed in a credit crunch triggered by the Russian-ruble crisis of 1998, and we predicted that it might not be so lucky in the inevitable next seize-up in credit. The stock was then selling near its all-time high of 65.   Subsequently, in "Coming Home to Roost" (Feb. 13, 2006), we argued that New Century, then down to 38, was in the path of a likely tsunami of subprime-mortgage defaults. For the industry's credit standards, never high, had slipped notably, and a fall in housing prices seemed inevitable.   Finally, in a follow-up article on Feb. 12 of this year, with the stock around 19, we warned that the company could be laid low by the very kind of liquidity squeeze that subsequently occurred.   Now, the lender -- which boasted some $60 billion in mortgage underwritings last year -- has lost all of its credit lines, after failing to meet a number of margin calls from its bankers. This means that it can't make new mortgages or fund some to which it previously had committed. Its creditors want immediate repayment of $8.4 billion in loans on mortgages that New Century produced in recent months and is holding for securitization.   Sure, these bank loans are collateralized by $9 billion in inventoried mortgages. But in the fashion of Wall Street when it smells blood, bids on the inventory have been pulled, or drastically low-balled. New Century's creditors, many of whom are also buyers of its wares for securitization, would have little to lose should the company file for bankruptcy. There would be plenty of assets, including its mortgage inventory, to pick over. For Wall Street, the important thing is to use such a filing to grab as much value as possible from shareholders by buying assets on the cheap and making a killing on their resale.   Whether New Century will survive is unclear. It's under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department. Just last week, it received a subpoena requesting information from a grand jury probing whether there was illegal insider trading in its stock and possible accounting fraud before the company's disclosure last month that it would show a loss in the fourth quarter and would be restating downward results for 2006's first three quarters. The company said it hadn't reserved properly against a flood of impaired loans it was forced to take back from securitizers because the debtors had defaulted in the loans' first two months.   New Century also has been delisted by the Big Board. In pink-sheet trading, the stock (ticker: NEWC.PK) fell to 67 cents Wednesday. It jumped above $3 on Friday, then closed at $2.34, on news that subprime rival Accredited Home Lenders Holding (LEND) had escaped a bind similar to New Century's by selling some $2.7 billion of subprime mortgages for about 95 cents on the dollar.   There's probably still about $1.5 billion of equity at New Century. The big question: How much will be left for shareholders after claimants eat their fill?   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Turkey's Finansbank 2006 Net Pft Up 107% On Yr To TRY741M-IHA
Story: ISTANBUL (Dow Jones)--Turkish Finansbank AS (FINBN.IS) said its net profit increased in 2006 by 107% on-year to 741 million new lira ($529.2 million), the Ihlas News Agency, or IHA, reported.   Finansbank said in a statement late Friday that assets rose by 45% to TRY17.895 billion in 2006 compared with the previous year while its equity capital climbed last year by 43% on-year to TRY 2.155 billion.   The bank's pre-tax profit increased by 86% on-year to TRY1.209 billion.   Finansbank General Manager Sinan Sahinbas said the company increased the total number of people employed by 19% to 7.751 throughout the year and with the opening of 101 new branches the total number of the bank's branches currently stands at 309.   National Bank of Greece (NBG) had purchased a 46% stake of Finansbank for $2.7 billion from Turkish financial services company Fiba Group on April 3, 2006.   Established in 1987, Finansbank AS provides a range of corporate, investment and retail banking services primarily to medium-sized and large corporate customers in Turkey and abroad.   Agency Web sites: http://www.ihavideo.net and http://www.iha.com.tr     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 05:47 ET (09:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(3/17) Comcast Signals Unhappiness With Google
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Peter Grant   Comcast Corp. is negotiating to use Microsoft Corp.'s Internet search services on its broadband portal, a sign the cable titan isn't happy about its current search deal with Google Inc., according to people familiar with the matter.   Comcast, the country's largest cable operator, also has been talking to Google about extending their relationship. Currently, Google provides search results when users of the Comcast.net portal enter queries into the search box on the site. But Comcast thinks it should get a larger share of the revenue generated by the arrangement. It also is unhappy about other terms of the deal, these people say.   The negotiations are a sign of Comcast's efforts to flex its muscles beyond cable into the Internet business. The company, which has more than 24 million cable subscribers, is the nation's second-largest provider of high-speed Internet hookups, after AT&T Inc. Comcast also has begun developing its own entertainment Web sites such as fearnet.com and ziddio.com.   Google has shared advertising revenue from searches generated on Comcast.net, with Comcast's cut expected to be about $70 million this year, people familiar with the matter say. But Comcast feels that its share should be at least $100 million, these people say. Comcast.net, which gets about 15 million visitors a month, is one of the biggest non-Google sources of search queries handled by Google.   Comcast also maintains that Google could do more to boost the number of searches from Comcast.net, for instance by making it possible for users viewing a particular news story to search easily for both text and video on that subject. Comcast executives also argue that Google has not provided sufficient information on how it uses data from Comcast.net users.   Because of this dissatisfaction, Comcast asked other Internet companies to submit proposals, and currently it's talking to Microsoft, whose MSN unit is one of the largest search engines after Google and Yahoo. Google's current deal with Comcast expires at the end of this year. A Microsoft spokesman declined to comment.   Agreements with distribution partners usually are hard-fought by the Internet companies, and sometimes swing back and forth. Chinese computer maker Lenovo Group Ltd., for example, announced this past week that it planned to install Microsoft's toolbar software and set default search settings to its search service on PCs before they ship, replacing a similar arrangement with Google.   Comcast is expected to make a decision in weeks. Google had $10.6 billion in revenue last year, so an end to its Comcast arrangement would not likely affect its results significantly.   Comcast ultimately may decide to stay with Google because of Google's scale, clout with advertisers and the popularity of its search results. Google, on average, collects more advertising revenue per search than its competitors, at least in part because it displays ads that people are more likely to click on.   Besides search, Comcast also is looking for ways to increase advertising revenue from Comcast.net and its other sites. The cable company is talking to Microsoft, Yahoo Inc. and Time Warner Inc.'s AOL unit about a three-year deal to sell 80% of the advertising on Comcast.net, people said. Comcast is holding on to the other 20% and advertising on its other sites to help it build an in-house broadband sales staff.   A Google spokesman declined to comment.   ---   Kevin J. Delaney contributed to this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China International Marine Containers 2006 Net CNY2.77 Bln -2
Story: The Shenzhen-based firm's core revenue rose to CNY33.17 billion in 2006, from CNY30.96 billion a year earlier.   Looking ahead, the company said it is aiming to strengthen its leading position in the container industry by exploring new markets.   Analysts had expected CIMC's full-year results to continue to show the effects of industry overcapacity and falling prices in its core business of dry cargo containers.   CIMC reported a 19% drop in net profit for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2006, to CNY2.15 billion, with profit margins on containers down to 13.2% from 17.5% a year earlier.   However, the company's diversification into more specialized and profitable businesses, such as trailers used in road transport, was expected to limit the full-year decline in net profit, analysts said.   CIMC's largest shareholders are two shipping-related companies, state-owned China Ocean Shipping (Group) Co. and an arm of China Merchants Holdings (International) Co. (0144.HK).     -By China Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; djnews.shanghai@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 04:02 ET (08:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Tech Trader: St Microelectronics Shares As Pricey As A European Vacation
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   I'm used to seeing Europeans pay low multiples for their continent's tech stocks. That was before I saw where ST Microelectronics has been trading lately. The Geneva-based firm (ADR Ticker: STM) is one of the world's top five semiconductor companies, selling chips for wireless phones, digital cameras and video displays. Its sales have flattened. It is struggling to cut costs, get out of the profit-pinching memory business and keep up with tough rivals like Texas Instruments (TXN) and Qualcomm (QCOM). Yet at a recent $19 on the New York exchange (or about 14.30 euros in Paris or Milan), ST enjoys about twice the earnings multiple of the better-positioned TI. I'm just an American hayseed, but I don't get it.   The company is the product of a 1987 merger between Italian and French chip makers. Since taking over as chief executive in 2005, Carlo Bozotti has been working to increase ST's operating profits and cash flow. He's done a good job. By controlling expenses, ST's operating profit margin rose from 2.7% in 2005 to 6.9% in 2006. By clamping down on capital spending, ST more than doubled its free cash flow (that is, cash from operations minus capital spending) from less than 3% of sales in 2005 to 7.5% in 2006.   Overall, earnings more than doubled last year to 83 cents a share on an 11% rise in sales to $9.9 billion. The company's stock-market capitalization is about $17 billion.   To continue paring costs, ST hopes to hive off its flash- memory chip business. The memory unit has struggled to break even on sales that amounted to 16% of the company's total last year. The flash-memory market, which includes the memory chips used in cellphones, digital cameras and music players, is a heavyweight fight between Samsung and joint ventures that pair Toshiba and Sandisk (SNDK) and Intel (INTC) and Micron Technologies (MU).   Although ST is teamed with Korea's Hynix to make flash, it also makes a less popular kind of memory known as NOR chips. By unloading NOR memory, ST could escape the heavy capital investments needed to stay in the memory game. That's exactly what Advanced Micro Devices did when it spun off Spansion (SPSN) a year ago.   But it still takes plenty of expensive gear to make ST's other chip products. To share the cost of a leading-edge factory in Crolles, France, ST teamed up with Motorola and Phillips. That was before those partners spun off their chip businesses into Freescale Semiconductor and NXP Semiconductors, respectively. Now Freescale and NXP are owned by private-equity investors. NXP has given notice that it will bail from the Crolles alliance at the end of this year, and Freescale seems to be cozying up to IBM as its preferred manufacturing mate.   ST says that it wants to get out of chip manufacturing, anyway, by sending more of its products to outside foundries like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM). In doing that, ST is trying to take a page out of the playbook of Texas Instruments, which has lightened its capital spending in recent years by using foundries.   Bozotti's financial management has won plaudits on this side of the Atlantic, no doubt helping ST shares deliver their splendid performance in the past year. From the tech sector's bottom in July 2006, ST's stock has risen over 30%, which is nearly double the rise of the Philadelphia Semiconductor Stock Index, or SOXX.   ST has won Buy ratings from analysts like Mark Lipacis of Prudential Equity Group (who was out of pocket when I called his office  Friday). In his notes, Lipacis reports that ST has the industry's best cash- flow yields, given that its free cash flow should be better than 7% of his forecast for 2007 revenues. Texas Instruments ranks third, with about 5.2% (after accounting for stock buybacks that TI uses to offset employee stock options). The Prudential analyst says that such free cash-flow percentages were strong predictors of stock performance last year.   But ST's cost controls will only go so far, if its sales don't keep growing. Although full-year sales rose 11% in 2006, on a sequential basis sales flattened and then turned downward after the June 2006 quarter. In January, ST told investors to expect sales to slide 3%-11% sequentially in the quarter ending this month. ST bulls are banking on a sharp rebound in sales in the second half of the year.   I'm not sure I understand why. ST's cellular phone chips are positioned in the wrong part of that market. It has put its efforts into developing chips for feature-rich handsets designed for so-called Third Generation cellular networks. But most of the industry's growth lately has been in humble Second Generation products that sell cheaply.   Rivals like Texas Instruments have very low cost silicon for 2G phones that integrates nearly all the necessary chips in a single part. And TI is working on highly-integrated solutions for cheap 3G phones, as well. ST doesn't have single chip offerings for the "value cell phone" market and if pricing becomes tougher for both 2G and 3G chips, then ST will be hard pressed to maintain its margins. Imaging chips are another important business for ST. It's also a critical business for some head-butting rivals like Micron.   ST plans a big entrance this year into the market for Bluetooth chips, which allow headsets and other paraphernalia to go wireless. But Bluetooth is a hotly contested business, with tough rivals like Britain's CSR, Broadcom (BRCM) and the doughty wireless chip maker Atheros Communications (ATHR). That doesn't look like the place to go for a revenue rebound.   The visibility's not great, therefore, on an ST sales revival. So why does it trade for 23 times trailing earnings, while Texas Instruments trades for 11 times? Well, both ST and the German chip maker Infineon (IFX) have been flagged as potential buyout candidates that private equity buyers could load up with debt -- like Freescale. So much private equity money is looking for work these days that you can't rule out any deal, but ST's challenges look kind of difficult to this yokel.   ---   E-mail: william.alpert@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.   Callon Petroleum - CPE-NYSE   Market Perform - Price 13.94 on March 13   by Raymond James   CPE reported net income per diluted share of 27 cents, beating our estimate of 24 cents and matching consensus. Higher-than-expected production and realized pricing provided most of the upside to our estimate. Production in 4Q06. . . [was] up 216% year-over-year [but] vast majority of growth is due to post-hurricane restoration. . . . reserves are now down a total [of] 56% from 2000, and have declined six consecutive years. . . . CPE is purchasing BP's 80% interest in Entrada for $190 million, adding 150 billions of cubic feet equivalent of proven reserves, more than doubling CPE's proven reserve base, but even with this, it is still below 2000 levels. . . . We are reducing our '07 earnings-per-share estimate from $1.50 to 72 cents and our '08 EPS estimate from $2.24 to $1.65. We still think Callon is reasonably priced, trading at 4 times '08 estimated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Yet due to reserve [declines], high leverage associated with the acquisition and. . . risk associated with having a majority of proven reserves in a single field, we're downgrading CPE from Outperform to Market Perform.   Color Kinetics - CLRK-NNM   Buy Price 18.68 on March 13   by Think Equity   Maintaining Buy and target of 28, which represents a 33 times multiple of our pro forma 2008E EPS of 72 cents, in line with CLRK's current multiple of 31 times our calendar-year '07 EPS estimate of 50 cents. . . . [We believe] CLRK's three- to five-year earnings growth rate will be greater than 40%-45%. We expect to see the adoption of solid-state illumination gain momentum as the efficiency and pricing of LEDs [improve]. Given the sizeable opportunity and CLRK's position as a market leader, we believe that CLRK shares will command a high earnings multiple for many years to come.   Dollar Tree Stores - DLTR-NNM   Peer Perform - Price 36.66 on March 13   by Bear Stearns   Upgrading to Peer Perform from Underperform. DLTR is currently trading at 8.4 times trailing Ebitda. In light of the announced takeover [of] Dollar General at an estimated 12 times trailing Ebitda, we believe the risk/reward is even. While DLTR has been able to drive top line sales effectively, operating income growth has lagged. In 2006, operating income increased 9.5% on a sales gain of 17%. DLTR starts cycling tougher comparisons this year and is adding more food to its sales mix, which could pressure margins. DLTR shares are trading at 18 times our 2007 post-stock option EPS estimate of $2, in line with their historical range of 16 to 18 times forward estimates over the last three to five years. . . . We do not think that DLTR is a buyer of Dollar General, as a deal would likely be dilutive, given current offer from KKR. Yet we believe dollar-store industry will consolidate long-term and that such a transaction would jump start DLTR's foray into a multiple-price-point format.   Genitope - GTOP-NNM   Hold - Price 3.41 on March 13   by W.R. Hambrecht   Fourth-quarter loss exceeded expectations, but the company has sufficient cash to fund operations through the end of 2007. We believe the driver remains the Phase III MyVax data in follicular non-Hodgkins lymphoma that are expected in Q407. We remain cautious on the outcome of this trial. Given the binary nature of the data on GTOP's stock, we maintain our Hold rating.   Mid-America Apartment Communities - MAA-NYSE   Outperform Price 53.89 on March 13   by Morgan Keegan   MAA has significantly underperformed its multifamily peers within the past several months, creating an attractive entry point. MAA shares trade at nearly a 25% discount to multifamily sector [funds-from-operations] multiples, and at a 15% [funds available for distribution] multiple discount. The current price represents a 9% discount to our $59.02 per share net-asset-value estimate. We are upgrading MAA from Market Perform to Outperform based on valuation.   Pacific Asia China Energy/PACE - PCEEF-Other OTC   Speculative Buy - Price 55 cents on March 12   by Dutton Associates   PACE, through a joint venture with Mitchell Drilling, has signed a multicompany degasification contract with Shenhua Ningxia Coal Group of Shenhua Group, China's largest coal producer, which is valued in excess of [U.S. $7.8 million] and provides turnkey operation [to] include 44,000 meters of. . . drilling. . . . The joint venture expects to receive about 55% of the total contract value. . . . PACE disclosed that other foreign operators of coalbed-methane projects in China have expressed interest in using the joint-venture technology. 12-month target: $1.   Strategic Hotels - BEE-NYSE   Market Perform - Price 21.93 on March 9   by Wachovia Securities   There's leveraged-buyout chatter stemming from a competitor who reports private-equity firms are assembling bids to pursue acquisition of BEE. We estimate net asset value at roughly 24 per share, but have been reluctant to upgrade BEE because: we're not wholly convinced CEO Laurence Geller is a willing seller now despite BEE's recent challenges; and concern that BEE may announce a significant multiyear renovation program that could be disruptive to future cash-flow growth, financial leverage, and ultimately NAV.   Wells Fargo & Co. - WFC-NYSE   Outperform - Price 34.50 on March 12   by RBC Capital Markets   Virtually all WFC's subprime mortgage originations in '06 were securitized and sold into the secondary market or made under co-issue arrangements whereby Wells only services the loans for a fee. The only subprime loans. . . are those generated by consumer-finance division Wells Fargo Financial; these are mostly debt consolidation loans -- only part of the real estate-secured portfolio and just 7% of Wells Fargo's total loans outstanding. While Wells Fargo's credit quality continues to hold up well, the stock could still be exposed to further headline risk should the subprime meltdown continue. Beyond that, there could be some modest risk to revenues through lower servicing fees or lower gains on the origination/sale of loans. At this point, we remain confident WFC will continue to post above-average revenue and earnings growth relative to most other large-cap banks. As such, we are leaving our 2007 and 2008 EPS estimates unchanged at $2.73 and $3.00, respectively. With the stock trading at a rare 5%-10% discount to the group, compared to a 10%-15% premium historically, we believe the recent selloff represents an attractive buying opportunity. Our 12-month target, 41 (15 times our 2007 EPS estimate), still conservatively assumes only a 5%-10% premium relative to the S&P 500 Bank Composite. Reiterate Outperform/Average Risk.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Top Auto Executives To Meet With Bush Later This Month
Story: DETROIT (AP)--President George W. Bush and top executives of Detroit's three automakers plan to meet again in Washington later this month to discuss increased use of flexible and alternative fuels.   No date has been set for the meeting, to take place at the White House, but Colin McBean, manager of Washington communications for DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX), said the talks likely will center on alternatives to gasoline and diesel fuel such as ethanol and biodiesel-powered vehicles.   "There's interest among the respective parties to discuss flexible fuel as well as alternative fuels," McBean said Friday.   The White House would not confirm that the meeting is on Bush's schedule, but a spokesman said the administration stays in contact with the automakers on alternative fuels and other issues.   "We look forward to working with them to reduce gasoline usage," said spokesman Alex Conant.   Bush last met with General Motors Corp. (GM) Chairman and Chief Executive Rick Wagoner, Ford Motor Co. (F) CEO Alan Mulally and DaimlerChrysler AG's Chrysler Group CEO Tom LaSorda in November, promising continued dialogue on trade, health care and other issues.   The president was criticized by Sen. Debbie Stabenow, a Michigan Democrat, for not meeting with the executives sooner.   Since then, Bush, in his State of the Union address, proposed reducing gasoline use by 20% over the next 10 years. He called for ramping up the production of alternative fuels such as ethanol made from new, non-corn feedstocks, and he called on Congress to require the annual use of 35 billion gallons of ethanol and other alternative fuels such as biodiesel by 2017, a fivefold increase over current requirements.   Earlier this month Bush arranged with Brazil for the two countries to share ethanol production technology.   Next week, the president is scheduled to tour two Kansas City, Mo.-area auto assembly plants and discuss his plan to reduce fuel consumption.   Spokesmen for Ford and GM wouldn't say Friday whether a meeting between the president and the auto executives had been arranged.   Stabenow said another meeting is a good step, but she said Bush needs to allocate more money to alternative fuel and battery technology development.   "We need to see a boldness coming from the president's budget on alternative fuels," she said.   She expects the executives and Bush to discuss increasing the number of filling stations that have ethanol and biofuels. While incentives have been successful in developing alternative fuels, the infrastructure isn't in place to get them to consumers, she said.   Conant said Bush is taking action on alternative fuels, making energy independence a priority in his State of the Union address and is working with Congress on gasoline use reduction goals.   Last year the leaders of GM, Ford and DaimlerChrysler said that by 2010 they would double their production of flexible fuel vehicles, which can run on blends of 85% ethanol and 15% gasoline.   They have targeted building 2 million of these vehicles a year by 2010, but note the lack of fueling stations that carry the ethanol blends. Less than 1% of the nation's 170,000 gas stations offer E85, and most are found in the Midwest.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 03:27 ET (07:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Barron's Online: Forest Grumps: Weyerhaeuser Insiders Unload Big Holdings
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Naureen S. Malik   WEYERHAEUSER EXECUTIVES ARE HARVESTING HEFTY GAINS AS THE STOCK hovers around record highs and the timber producer faces mounting pressure to convert into a real-estate investment trust.   Over the past 30 days, 13 senior executives of Weyerhaeuser (ticker: WY) sold more than 787,000 shares for roughly $70.7 million, according to Insider-   Score.com data. All shares were sold at prices ranging from $80.05 to $84.67; the stock was at 79 late last week.   Insidersalso exercised options for about 804,000 shares in the past month for $44 million, or from $49.61 to $69.73 per share, and were not set to expire for a couple of years, according to Thomson Financial.   It was the company's highest level of monthly selling ever, based on data going back to 1999.   Weyerhaeuser spokesman Bruce Amundson said that senior management and other parties familiar with a recent acquisition had been "precluded from trading the stock" due to a blackout period (related to an acquisition) from July 2006 to March 8.   Michael Painchaud, managing director of research for Market Profile Theorems, says that insider selling has painted a bearish picture at Weyerhaeuser-one matched with downbeat analysts-while "the markets are overly enthusiastic" about the stock.   Statistical analysis of Weyerhaeuser and the broader market indicates that "these kinds of situations would suggest we would see price weakness now" at the lumber company, says Painchaud.   The largest inside seller in this latest wave was Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President Steven Rogel. In fact, Rogel sold all the shares he directly owned. On March 8, Rogel grossed $29.83 million by selling on the open market 356,397 shares that were acquired through options for $18.9 million, Securities and Exchange Commission filings show. Those options hadn't been set to expire until the period February 2009 through February 2011. Weyerhaeuser's annual proxy statement, released March 9, indicates Rogel continues to hold options exercisable for 1.09 million shares. Rogel's total compensation package for 2006 was nearly $4.07 million, including a salary of $1.29 million and a bonus of $1.3 million that represents 80% of his target award.   The stock touched a record high of $87.09 onFeb. 27, but has fallen nearly 6% since then amid a broad market drop. So far this year, Weyerhaeuser shares are up 13%, on par with forestry peers. Still, it's trading at 28 times earnings-per-share estimates for the next four quarters. That gives the stock a roughly 26% premiumto the forest-products industry, while in the past it has traded at a discount averaging 19%.   Shareholders are pressuring Weyerhaeuser to change its status as a corporation to a REIT with better tax benefits and where gains are passed on to investors, but it is unclear whether the push will succeed. One hurdle: The company "may have to sell everything but timberland to qualify" forREITstatus, according to UBS analyst Richard Schneider. Headline: CME Chair Duffy: CME Has Definitive Agreement On CBOT Merger-2
Story: ICE's entry into the fray this week further complicates CME's bid for CBOT, which was already plagued by concerns that it would create a monopoly in the interest-rate futures and options market. CME had hoped the deal would be approved by antitrust authorities by midyear.   Duffy's emphasis on CME's clearing and technological strengths highlights one of the potential advantages it has over its competition.   ICE acquired a clearing facility in January with the acquisition of Nybot. Industry watchers have queried whether it will be able to handle the increased business from a merger with CBOT.   Duffy added that CME has invested $1 billion in technology over the past seven years.   CBOT chairman Charles Carey wouldn't be drawn Saturday on when his executives would meet to discuss ICE's proposal.   "We'll be having lots of board meetings," he told Dow Jones Newswires.     -By Emily Barrett and Matt Chambers, Dow Jones Newswires     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 11:39 ET (15:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Taking The Long View
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By J.R. Brandstrader   Interview with   S. Basu Mullick   Manager   Neuberger Berman Partners Fund     Many investors claim to emulate warren Buffett, but S. Basu Mullick, manager of the $4 billion Neuberger Berman Partners Fund (ticker: NBPBX), had good reason to invoke the teachings of the Great One last month when day traders hammered one of his favorite stocks, Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold (FCX). Mullick held tight as the stock plummeted 10%, to 56, on Feb. 27, amid concerns the plunge in Asian markets would depress demand for copper.   "Buffett doesn't trade," says Mullick, who bought Freeport at 52 a share, and thinks it should sell for 80, or 10 times 2007 estimated earnings of $8 per share. "He holds on to stocks for 36 years."   Buffett has said his favorite holding period is forever, a luxury mutual-fund managers don't have. Mullick, 48, managing director and portfolio manager on Neuberger's mid-cap value and large-cap value teams, says his annual turnover is a conservative 30% or so, including inflows, and "there are almost no capital gains."   Nevertheless, like Buffett, he refuses to follow the crowd when his insights and instinct lead elsewhere. In the case of Freeport, he says, the company is run by shareholder-oriented managers and should be able to pay down debt faster than the market expects after the recent purchase of Phelps Dodge. Besides, he says, "the fundamental demand/supply balance of copper is strongly in favor of price stability at the current levels." The May copper contract was trading for $2.97 a pound last week. Freeport's stock has been moving up, hitting $60 last week. Mullick has no plans to sell.   That tenacity has generally worked well for investors in the no-load, large-blend value fund, although Neuberger Berman Partners is neck-and-neck with the Standard & Poor's 500 index year-to-date, down 1.92% versus the S&P's decline of 1.78%. Over the past 12 months, however, it has climbed only 6.37%, while the S&P was up 8.96%.   Yet in the three-year period, the fund beats 96% of its peers, up 13.82%, versus a 9.37% gain in the index; for the five-year stretch, it's up 8.78% -- once again ahead of the S&P's return, 5.65%. Morningstar awards the fund four stars out of five.   Mullick says he's fascinated by the interplay of macroeconomics and individual stock stories, as in the case of supply-and-demand trends in copper.   Even so, he's a bottom-up stock-picker, examining company fundamentals first and the economic trends that might affect them later. He aims to buy best-of-breed companies with high margins and returns, whose shares are trading at historically low valuations. Typically, Mullick looks for stocks whose price/earnings and price/cash flow multiples are at 10-year lows.   The fund usually holds 60 to 85 companies, with none accounting for more than 5% of assets. The average market capitalization of fund holdings is about $40 billion.   Mullick has three criteria for selling stocks. Either the fundamental investment case changes; a stock reaches his price objective; or it drops 30% and he is unwilling to double down.   Coal producer Peabody Energy (BTU), another holding, has taken a pounding of late. Two warm winters and the ready availability of nuclear and hydro power have depressed coal prices, while inventories have built. Peabody is the largest, most diversified producer of coal, the cheapest and most abundant source of baseload power. Mullick's take: "Peabody remains undervalued at a 10-year-low P/E," says Mullick, who bought the stock at 18 and thinks it could trade up to 55, from 38 now.   A weak coal market also has made Joy Global (JOYG) a bargain, according to Mullick, who believes the leader in surface- and underground-mining equipment, particularly for coal, is well positioned to benefit from operating leverage. Double-digit revenue growth will be driven by a solid backlog, he says, and cash flow is likely to exceed earnings per share, which should continue to grow by 20% or more. Joy is returning cash to shareholders, he notes, with a $1 billion stock repurchase program. The stock has dropped more than 10 points since Feb. 23, to around 42.   Another pick, Noble (NE) also has been on a roller-coaster ride, falling from 73.58 on Feb. 26 to 67.74, before bouncing back to about 74; Mullick bought the shares at 71. The offshore driller's valuation is at a 10-year low. "Clearly, the expectation is for energy services to have negative earnings revisions, but in the case of Noble, the market seems to have overdone it," he says. "We think stock has a fair value of $100-plus."   Mullick's investment style can produce white knuckles -- for the manager and his investors. Morningstar's David Kathman likes the no-load fund's competitive expense ratio of 1.14%, but warns that Neuberger Berman Partners is "capable of underperforming dramatically, as it did in 2002 and most of 2006."   Mullick's ability to stay cool while the market melts down may stem from the tempering he underwent in his first job as a metals analyst for PaineWebber. The year was 1982, the rust belt was in a near-depression and the sector was entering a 20-year bear market. "That was the hardest time to be a metals analyst," he says. "There is a recovery today because of an added leg to development . . . behind the Iron Curtain."   Mullick, who teaches portfolio management at New Jersey's Rutgers university, left PaineWebber in 1986 to join First Fidelity Bank as a portfolio manager. Two years later, he became a portfolio manager at John A. Levin, and in 1992 joined Omega Advisors to run a hedge fund. Chafing under the demand for short-term performance, he moved to Ark Asset Management and then, in 1998, to Neuberger Berman.   "We take a long view," says Mullick. "We're not going to outperform every year." Then again, neither does Buffett.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/19) Asian Trader: New Offerings Keep Blooming In China
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Rick Carew   In china, massive investor demand for new, higher-quality issues is translating into one of the world's most resilient markets for initial public offerings -- despite Shanghai's Feb. 27 tumble. And the pipeline in Hong Kong and Shanghai is stacked with investor favorites, like banks.   Over the period of a year, three of China's four biggest banks sold a whopping $42.3 billion worth of shares on the two exchanges, capped by the world-record $21.9 billion IPO of Industrial & Commercial Bank of China in October.   The great Chinese bank sale far exceeded expectations, feeding investor appetite for exposure to China's rapid economic growth, which soared 10.7% last year without stoking inflation. Investors see Chinese banks as the purest play on overall economic growth, due to their huge and varied lending portfolios and potential in the immature retail-banking market.   Now comes a slew of smaller Chinese banks ready to go to market. Demand for midsize national banks and city commercial banks, which primarily operate in one city, should rival that for bigger peers, analysts say; Hong Kong and Shanghai could see up to seven first-time offerings from smaller Chinese banks this year alone. Industrial Bank Co. kicked off the parade in January by selling $2.1 billion of shares in Shanghai -- the most sought-after IPO in the domestic market's history, with the retail tranche 129 times oversubscribed. (Hong Kong-traded shares are easily accessible to global investors, but Shanghai shares must go through the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor program.)   Investors often favor midsize banks -- and award them premiums -- since their scale lets them grow revenues, and hence profits, much faster than state banks. Investors also target high-growth niche markets like credit cards (China Merchants Bank) or small-and medium-sized enterprise lending (China Minsheng Banking). Industrial Bank's 369-branch network, concentrated in richer south China, makes it more flexible than Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, with its 18,000 scattered branches. And they handle risk management better. Meanwhile, smaller banks have been China's best performers in terms of asset quality.   At the end of 2006, midsize banks had an overall nonperforming-loan ratio of 2.81%; city commercial banks had a 4.87% NPL ratio; and China's three biggest listed state banks each needed multi-billion dollar bailouts to get their NPL ratios below 5%. Smaller banks haven't received similar government bailouts, although some have benefited from local-government or parent-company capital injections.   Analysts caution that the scarcity factor may fade, and later joiners could have trouble differentiating themselves. "Smaller banks can't be overly ambitious," says Jing Ulrich, JPMorgan's head of China equities. "Their shares should be [priced in an IPO] at a discount to what bigger banks are trading at today."   Peking University finance professor Michael Pettis believes Chinese banking stocks trade at high multiples of book value because they're technically insolvent and, thus, a bet on volatility. He compares them to call options or Internet stocks: They could do really well (if China keeps up 10% growth), or really badly (if China's economy slows, and loans go bad).   "In principle, smaller banks will trade at even higher multiples than the big banks because they generally have a regional focus, which makes them purer [and more volatile] bets on GDP growth, especially for banks in faster growing regions," he says.   ---   Rick Carew reports for Dow Jones Newswires in Beijing.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Potential Racing Post Suitors Putting Final Touches On Bids-FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Potential suitors for the Racing Post are putting final touches to their offers for the U.K.'s only racing daily ahead of the March 26 deadline, reports the Financial Times Saturday, citing the information memorandum from the seller's bankers Rothschild.   The paper reports Rupert Murdoch's News International, the holding company of News Corp.'s (NWS) U.K. publishing activities, the owner of The Sun and The Times newspapers, and private equity firms including DLJL, 3i and Exponent are understood to have indicated interest.   Trinity Mirror (TNI.LN), the newspaper publisher that is putting Racing Post up for sale and hopes to get an estimated GBP200 million for it, said it had a "healthy line-up across all types of buyers."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 07:08 ET (11:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: 5 Killed, 51 Hurt In Airliner Crash Landing In Russia
Story: (Adds details)     MOSCOW (AP)--A Russian airliner crash landed in the city of Samara on Saturday, killing five people and injuring 51, a spokesman for the Emergency Situations Ministry said.   Spokesman Viktor Beltsov described the accident as a "hard landing" of a Tu-134. The NTV television channel said the plane landed on its fuselage after the landing gear failed to come down.   The plane belonged to the Russian airline UTAir (TMAT.RS) and had 57 people on board, ministry spokeswoman Irina Andrianova said. She said there was no fire after the crash, but had no further details about how the accident occurred.   Samara is about 900 kilometers southeast of Moscow.   Tu-134s are widely used in the former Soviet Union. The plane that crashed was en route to Samara from Surgut, about 1,600 kilometers to the east.   The last major crash of a Russian airliner was on Aug. 22, when a Tu-154 of Pulkovo Airlines crashed in Ukraine, killing all 170 people aboard.   In July, an Airbus-310 of S7 airlines went off the runway after landing in Irkutsk, smashed into adjacent buildings and caught fire, killing 123 of the 203 people aboard. In May, an Armenian Airbus-320 crashed into the Black Sea while trying to land in the southern Russian city of Sochi, killing all 113 people aboard.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 05:11 ET (09:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: CVC Offer For Sainsbury Set For As Early As Next Wk-Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--J Sainsbury (SBRY.LN) is braced for a preliminary takeover offer from the private equity firm CVC and its partners of up to GBP9.5 billion as early as next week, reports The Times Saturday, without citing its sources.   The move comes as rival firms including Bain Capital and Apollo Management are known to be circling Sainsbury, the paper writes.   The Times reports it is believed that Bain and Apollo have held talks with Vornado Realty Trust (VNO), the New York real-estate investment trust, but haven't yet formed a formal consortium.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 17, 2007 07:03 ET (11:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
